Text

[I]0-i returned from [the City]240-the city about three o'clock on that May afternoon pretty well disgusted with life . [I]0-i had been three months in [the Old Country]241-the old country , and was fed up with it . If [anyone]242-anyone had told [me]0-i a year ago that [I]0-i would have been feeling like that [I]0-i should have laughed at [him]242-anyone ; but there was the fact . The weather made [me]0-i liverish , the talk of [the ordinary Englishman]243-the ordinary englishman made [me]0-i sick . [I]0-i could n't get enough exercise , and the amusements of [London]1-london seemed as flat as soda - water that has been standing in the sun . ' [Richard Hannay]140-mr hannay , '[0-i] [I]0-i kept telling [myself]0-i , ' [you]140-mr hannay have got into [the wrong ditch]1416-the wrong ditch , [[my]0-i friend]1417-my friend , and [you]140-mr hannay had better climb out . '[0-i] It made [me]0-i bite [my]0-i lips to think of the plans [I]0-i had been building up those last years in [Bulawayo]2-bulawayo . [I]0-i had got [my]0-i pile - not one of the big ones , but good enough for [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i had figured out all kinds of ways of enjoying [myself]0-i . [[My]0-i father]244-my father had brought [me]0-i out from [Scotland]3-scotland at the age of six , and [I]0-i had never been [home]245-home since ; so [England]4-england was a sort of [Arabian Nights]5-arabian nights to [me]0-i , and [I]0-i counted on stopping [there]246-there for the rest of [my]0-i days . But from the first [I]0-i was disappointed with it . In about a week [I]0-i was tired of seeing sights , and in less than a month [I]0-i had had enough of [restaurants]247-restaurants and [theatres]248-theatres and race - meetings . [I]0-i had [no real pal]249-no real pal to go about with , which probably explains things . [Plenty of people]250-plenty of people invited [me]0-i to [[their]250-plenty of people houses]251-their houses , but [they]250-plenty of people did n't seem much interested in [me]0-i . [They]250-plenty of people would fling [me]0-i a question or two about [South Africa]6-south africa , and then get on [their]250-plenty of people own affairs . [A lot of Imperialist ladies]252-a lot of imperialist ladies asked [me]0-i to tea to meet [schoolmasters from [New Zealand]7-new zealand]253-schoolmasters from new zealand and editors from [Vancouver]8-vancouver , and that was the dismalest business of all . Here was [I]0-i , thirty - seven years old , sound in wind and limb , with enough money to have a good time , yawning [my]0-i head off all day . [I]0-i had just about settled to clear out and get back to [the veld]254-the veld , for [I]0-i was [the best bored man in [the United Kingdom]256-the united kingdom]255-the best bored man in the united kingdom . That afternoon [I]0-i had been worrying [[my]0-i brokers]257-my brokers about investments to give [my]0-i mind something to work on , and on [my]0-i way [home]245-home [I]0-i turned into [[my]0-i club]259-my club - rather [a pot - house]260-a pot - house , which took in [Colonial members]261-colonial members . [I]0-i had a long drink , and read the evening papers . [They]262-they were full of the row in [the Near East]263-the near east , and there was an article about [Karolides]141-karolides , [the Greek Premier]264-the greek premier . [I]0-i rather fancied [the chap]265-the chap . From all accounts [he]141-karolides seemed [the one big man in the show]266-the one big man in the show ; and [he]141-karolides played a straight game too , which was more than could be said for most of [them]262-they . [I]0-i gathered that [they]262-they hated [him]141-karolides pretty blackly in [Berlin]9-berlin and [Vienna]10-vienna , but that [we]267-we were going to stick by [him]141-karolides , and one paper said that [he]141-karolides was the only barrier between [Europe]11-europe and [Armageddon]12-armageddon . [I]0-i remember wondering if [I]0-i could get a job in those parts . It struck [me]0-i that [Albania]13-albania was [the sort of place that might keep [a man]269-a man from yawning]268-the sort of place that might keep a man from yawning . About six o'clock [I]0-i went [home]245-home , dressed , dined at [the Cafe Royal]271-the cafe royal , and turned into [a music - hall]272-a music - hall . It was a silly show , [all capering women]273-all capering women and [monkey - faced men]274-monkey - faced men , and [I]0-i did not stay long . The night was fine and clear as [I]0-i walked back to [the flat [I]0-i had hired near [Portland Place]14-portland place]275-the flat i had hired near portland place . [The crowd]276-the crowd surged past [me]0-i on the pavements , busy and chattering , and [I]0-i envied [the people]277-the people for having something to do . [These shop - girls]278-these shop - girls and [clerks]279-clerks and [dandies]280-dandies and [policemen]281-policemen had some interest in life that kept [them]277-the people going . [I]0-i gave half - a - crown to [a beggar]282-a beggar because [I]0-i saw [him]282-a beggar yawn ; [he]282-a beggar was [a fellow - sufferer]283-a fellow - sufferer . At [Oxford Circus]15-oxford circus [I]0-i looked up into the spring sky and [I]0-i made a vow . [I]0-i would give [the Old Country]241-the old country another day to fit [me]0-i into something ; if nothing happened , [I]0-i would take [the next boat]285-the next boat for [the Cape]16-the cape . [[My]0-i flat]286-my flat was [the first floor in [a new block behind [Langham Place]17-langham place]288-a new block behind langham place]287-the first floor in a new block behind langham place . There was a common staircase , with [a porter]289-a porter and [a liftman]290-a liftman at the entrance , but there was [no restaurant]291-no restaurant or anything of that sort , and [each flat]292-each flat was quite shut off from [the others]293-the others . [I]0-i hate [servants on [the premises]295-the premises]294-servants on the premises , so [I]0-i had [a fellow]296-a fellow to look after [me]0-i who came in by the day . [He]296-a fellow arrived before eight o'clock every morning and used to depart at seven , for [I]0-i never dined at [home]245-home . [I]0-i was just fitting [my]0-i key into the door when [I]0-i noticed [a man]269-a man at [my]0-i elbow . [I]0-i had not seen [him]269-a man approach , and the sudden appearance made [me]0-i start . [He]269-a man was [a slim man , with a short brown beard and small , gimlety blue eyes]299-a slim man , with a short brown beard and small , gimlety blue eyes . [I]0-i recognized [him]269-a man as [the occupant of [a flat on [the top floor]302-the top floor , with whom [I]0-i had passed the time of day on the stairs]301-a flat on the top floor , with whom i had passed the time of day on the stairs]300-the occupant of a flat on the top floor , with whom i had passed the time of day on the stairs . ' Can [I]269-a man speak to [you]0-i ? '[269-a man] [he]269-a man said . ' May [I]269-a man come in for a minute ? '[269-a man] [He]269-a man was steadying [his]269-a man voice with an effort , and [his]269-a man hand was pawing [my]0-i arm . [I]0-i got [my]0-i door open and motioned [him]269-a man in . No sooner was [he]269-a man over the threshold than [he]269-a man made a dash for [[my]0-i back room]303-my back room , where [I]0-i used to smoke and write [my]0-i letters . Then [he]269-a man bolted back . ' Is the door locked ? '[269-a man] [he]269-a man asked feverishly , and [he]269-a man fastened the chain with [his]269-a man own hand . ' [I]269-a man 'm[269-a man] very sorry , ' [he]269-a man said humbly . '[269-a man] It 's a mighty liberty , but [you]0-i looked the kind of man who would understand . [I]0-i 've had [you]0-i in [my]0-i mind all this week when things got troublesome . Say , will [you]0-i do [me]0-i a good turn ? ' '[0-i] [I]0-i 'll listen to [you]269-a man , ' [I]0-i said . '[0-i] That 's all [I]0-i 'll promise . ' [I]0-i was getting worried by the antics of [this nervous little chap]1418-this nervous little chap . There was a tray of drinks on a table beside [him]269-a man , from which [he]269-a man filled [himself]269-a man a stiff whisky - and - soda . [He]269-a man drank it off in three gulps , and cracked the glass as [he]269-a man set it down . '[0-i] Pardon , ' [he]269-a man said , '[0-i] [I]0-i 'm a bit rattled tonight . [You]0-i see , [I]0-i happen at this moment to be dead . '[0-i] [I]0-i sat down in an armchair and lit [my]0-i pipe . ' What does it feel like ? '[0-i] [I]0-i asked . [I]0-i was pretty certain that [I]0-i had to deal with [a madman]304-a madman . A smile flickered over [his]0-i drawn face . ' [I]0-i 'm[0-i] not mad - yet . Say , [Sir]305-sir , [I]0-i 've been watching [you]305-sir , and [I]0-i reckon [you]305-sir 're [a cool customer]1419-a cool customer . [I]0-i reckon , too , [you]305-sir 're[0-i] [an honest man]306-an honest man , and not afraid of playing a bold hand . [I]0-i 'm going to confide in [you]305-sir . [I]0-i need help worse than [any man]1420-any man ever needed it , and [I]0-i want to know if [I]0-i can count [you]305-sir in . '[0-i] ' Get on with [your]305-sir yarn , '[0-i] [I]0-i said , ' and [I]0-i 'll tell [you]305-sir . '[0-i] [He]305-sir seemed to brace [himself]305-sir for a great effort , and then started on [the queerest rigmarole]307-the queerest rigmarole . [I]0-i did n't get hold of it at first , and [I]0-i had to stop and ask [him]305-sir questions . But here is the gist of it : [He]305-sir was [an American]308-an american , from [Kentucky]18-kentucky , and after college , being pretty well off , [he]305-sir had started out to see [the world]309-the world . [He]305-sir wrote a bit , and acted as [war correspondent for a [Chicago]19-chicago paper]310-war correspondent for a chicago paper , and spent a year or two in [South - Eastern Europe]20-south - eastern europe . [I]0-i gathered that [he]305-sir was [a fine linguist]311-a fine linguist , and had got to know pretty well the society in those parts . [He]305-sir spoke familiarly of many names that [I]0-i remembered to have seen in the newspapers . [He]305-sir had played about with politics , [he]305-sir told [me]0-i , at first for the interest of [them]312-them , and then because [he]305-sir could n't help [himself]305-sir . [I]0-i read [him]305-sir as [a sharp , restless fellow , who always wanted to get down to the roots of things]313-a sharp , restless fellow , who always wanted to get down to the roots of things . [He]305-sir got a little further down than [he]305-sir wanted . [I]0-i am giving [you]314-you what [he]305-sir told [me]0-i as well as [I]0-i could make it out . Away behind all [the Governments]315-the governments and [the armies]316-the armies there was a big subterranean movement going on , engineered by [very dangerous people]317-very dangerous people . [He]305-sir had come on it by accident ; it fascinated [him]305-sir ; [he]305-sir went further , and then [he]305-sir got caught . [I]0-i gathered that [most of [the people in it]319-the people in it]318-most of the people in it were [the sort of educated anarchists that make revolutions]320-the sort of educated anarchists that make revolutions , but that beside [them]318-most of the people in it there were [financiers who were playing for money]321-financiers who were playing for money . [A clever man]322-a clever man can make big profits on a falling market , and it suited the book of both classes to set [Europe]11-europe by the ears . [He]305-sir told [me]0-i some queer things that explained a lot that had puzzled [me]0-i - things that happened in the Balkan War , how [one state]323-one state suddenly came out on top , why alliances were made and broken , why [certain men]324-certain men disappeared , and where the sinews of war came from . The aim of the whole conspiracy was to get [Russia]21-russia and [Germany]22-germany at loggerheads . When [I]0-i asked why , [he]305-sir said that [the anarchist lot]325-the anarchist lot thought it would give [them]325-the anarchist lot [their]325-the anarchist lot chance . Everything would be in the melting - pot , and [they]325-the anarchist lot looked to see [a new world]326-a new world emerge . [The capitalists]327-the capitalists would rake in the shekels , and make fortunes by buying up wreckage . [Capital]328-capital , [he]305-sir said , had no conscience and [no fatherland]329-no fatherland . Besides , [the Jew]330-the jew was behind it , and [the Jew]330-the jew hated [Russia]21-russia worse than hell . ' Do [you]0-i wonder ? '[305-sir] [he]305-sir cried . ' For three hundred years [they]330-the jew have been persecuted , and this is the return match for the pogroms . [The Jew]330-the jew is everywhere , but [you]0-i have to go far down the backstairs to find [him]330-the jew . Take any big Teutonic business concern . [[My]25-the british government friends]1430-my friends are not playing this game for candy . [He]141-karolides 'll be murdered by [an Austrian]1439-an austrian , and there 'll be plenty of evidence to show the connivance of [the big folk in [Vienna]10-vienna and [Berlin]9-berlin]1440-the big folk in vienna and berlin . ' [I]148-scudder reckon it 's like going to sleep when [you]1489-you are pretty well tired out , and waking to find a summer day with the scent of hay coming in at the window . '[148-scudder] Next day [he]148-scudder was much more cheerful , and read the life of [Stonewall Jackson]155-stonewall jackson much of the time . [I]0-i went out to dinner with [a mining engineer]418-a mining engineer [I]0-i had got to see on business , and came back about half - past ten in time for [our]419-our game of chess before turning in . [I]0-i had a cigar in [my]0-i mouth , [I]0-i remember , as [I]0-i pushed open the smoking - room door . The lights were not lit , which struck [me]0-i as odd . [I]0-i wondered if [Scudder]148-scudder had turned in already . [I]0-i snapped the switch , but there was [nobody there]420-nobody there . Then [I]0-i saw something in the far corner which made [me]0-i drop [my]0-i cigar and fall into a cold sweat . [[My]0-i guest]421-my guest was lying sprawled on [his]421-my guest back . There was a long knife through [his]421-my guest heart which skewered [him]421-my guest to the floor . [I]0-i sat down in an armchair and felt very sick . That lasted for maybe five minutes , and was succeeded by a fit of the horrors . The poor staring white face on the floor was more than [I]0-i could bear , and [I]0-i managed to get a table - cloth and cover it . Then [I]0-i staggered to a cupboard , found the brandy and swallowed several mouthfuls . [I]0-i had seen [men]422-men die violently before ; indeed [I]0-i had killed [a few [myself]0-i in the Matabele War]423-a few myself in the matabele war ; but this cold - blooded indoor business was different . Still [I]0-i managed to pull [myself]0-i together . [I]0-i looked at [my]0-i watch , and saw that it was half - past ten . An idea seized [me]0-i , and [I]0-i went over [the flat]424-the flat with a small - tooth comb . There was [nobody there]420-nobody there , nor any trace of [anybody]426-anybody , but [I]0-i shuttered and bolted all the windows and put the chain on the door . By this time [my]0-i wits were coming back to [me]0-i , and [I]0-i could think again . It took [me]0-i about an hour to figure the thing out , and [I]0-i did not hurry , for , unless [the murderer]427-the murderer came back , [I]0-i had till about six o'clock in the morning for [my]0-i cogitations . [I]0-i was in the soup - that was pretty clear . Any shadow of a doubt [I]0-i might have had about the truth of [Scudder]148-scudder 's tale was now gone . The proof of it was lying under the table - cloth . [The men who knew that [he]148-scudder knew what [he]148-scudder knew]428-the men who knew that he knew what he knew had found [him]148-scudder , and had taken the best way to make certain of [his]148-scudder silence . Yes ; but [he]148-scudder had been in [[my]0-i rooms]429-my rooms four days , and [[his]148-scudder enemies]430-his enemies must have reckoned that [he]148-scudder had confided in [me]0-i . So [I]0-i would be the next to go . It might be that very night , or next day , or the day after , but [my]0-i number was up all right . Then suddenly [I]0-i thought of another probability . Supposing [I]0-i went out now and called in [the police]1436-the police , or went to bed and let [Paddock]151-paddock find the body and call [them]1436-the police in the morning . What kind of a story was [I]0-i to tell about [Scudder]148-scudder ? [I]0-i had lied to [Paddock]151-paddock about [him]148-scudder , and the whole thing looked desperately fishy . If [I]0-i made a clean breast of it and told [the police]1436-the police everything [he]148-scudder had told [me]0-i , [they]1436-the police would simply laugh at [me]0-i . The odds were a thousand to one that [I]0-i would be charged with the murder , and the circumstantial evidence was strong enough to hang [me]0-i . [Few people]433-few people knew [me]0-i in [England]4-england ; [I]0-i had [no real pal who could come forward and swear to [my]0-i character]434-no real pal who could come forward and swear to my character . Perhaps that was what [those secret enemies]435-those secret enemies were playing for . [They]435-those secret enemies were clever enough for anything , and [an English prison]436-an english prison was as good a way of getting rid of [me]0-i till after June 15th as a knife in [my]0-i chest . Besides , if [I]0-i told the whole story , and by any miracle was believed , [I]0-i would be playing [their]435-those secret enemies game . [Karolides]141-karolides would stay at [home]245-home , which was what [they]435-those secret enemies wanted . Somehow or other the sight of [Scudder]148-scudder 's dead face had made [me]0-i a passionate believer in [his]148-scudder scheme . [He]148-scudder was gone , but [he]148-scudder had taken [me]0-i into [his]148-scudder confidence , and [I]0-i was pretty well bound to carry on [his]148-scudder work . [You]438-you may think this ridiculous for [a man in danger of [his]439-a man in danger of his life life]439-a man in danger of his life , but that was the way [I]0-i looked at it . [I]0-i am [an ordinary sort of fellow]440-an ordinary sort of fellow , not braver than [other people]441-other people , but [I]0-i hate to see [a good man]442-a good man downed , and that long knife would not be the end of [Scudder]148-scudder if [I]0-i could play the game in [his]148-scudder place . It took [me]0-i an hour or two to think this out , and by that time [I]0-i had come to a decision . [I]0-i must vanish somehow , and keep vanished till the end of the second week in June . Then [I]0-i must somehow find a way to get in touch with [the Government people]443-the government people and tell [them]443-the government people what [Scudder]148-scudder had told [me]0-i . [I]0-i wished to [Heaven]156-heaven [he]148-scudder had told [me]0-i more , and that [I]0-i had listened more carefully to the little [he]148-scudder had told [me]0-i . [I]0-i knew nothing but the barest facts . There was a big risk that , even if [I]0-i weathered the other dangers , [I]0-i would not be believed in the end . [I]0-i must take [my]0-i chance of that , and hope that something might happen which would confirm [my]0-i tale in the eyes of [the Government]444-the government . [My]0-i first job was to keep going for the next three weeks . It was now the 24th day of May , and that meant twenty days of hiding before [I]0-i could venture to approach the powers that be . [I]0-i reckoned that [two sets of [people]446-people]445-two sets of people would be looking for [me]0-i - [[Scudder]148-scudder 's enemies]447-scudder 's enemies to put [me]0-i out of existence , and [the police]1436-the police , who would want [me]0-i for [Scudder]148-scudder 's murder . It was going to be a giddy hunt , and it was queer how the prospect comforted [me]0-i . [I]0-i had been slack so long that almost any chance of activity was welcome . When [I]0-i had to sit alone with that corpse and wait on [Fortune]157-fortune [I]0-i was no better than a crushed worm , but if [my]0-i neck 's safety was to hang on [my]0-i own wits [I]0-i was prepared to be cheerful about it . [My]0-i next thought was whether [Scudder]148-scudder had any papers about [him]148-scudder to give [me]0-i a better clue to the business . [I]0-i drew back the table - cloth and searched [his]148-scudder pockets , for [I]0-i had no longer any shrinking from the body . The face was wonderfully calm for [a man who had been struck down in a moment]449-a man who had been struck down in a moment . There was nothing in the breast - pocket , and only a few loose coins and a cigar - holder in the waistcoat . The trousers held a little penknife and some silver , and the side pocket of [his]148-scudder jacket contained an old crocodile - skin cigar - case . There was no sign of the little black book in which [I]0-i had seen [him]148-scudder making notes . That had no doubt been taken by [[his]148-scudder murderer]450-his murderer . But as [I]0-i looked up from [my]0-i task [I]0-i saw that some drawers had been pulled out in the writing - table . [Scudder]148-scudder would never have left them in that state , for [he]148-scudder was the tidiest of [mortals]451-mortals . [Someone]452-someone must have been searching for something - perhaps for the pocket - book . [I]0-i went round [the flat]424-the flat and found that everything had been ransacked - the inside of books , drawers , cupboards , boxes , even the pockets of the clothes in [my]0-i wardrobe , and the sideboard in [the dining - room]454-the dining - room . There was no trace of the book . Most likely [the enemy]455-the enemy had found it , but [they]455-the enemy had not found it on [Scudder]148-scudder 's body . Then [I]0-i got out an atlas and looked at a big map of [the British Isles]40-the british isles . [My]0-i notion was to get off to [some wild district]456-some wild district , where [my]0-i veldcraft would be of some use to [me]0-i , for [I]0-i would be like a trapped rat in [a city]457-a city . [I]0-i considered that [Scotland]3-scotland would be best , for [[my]0-i people]458-my people were [Scotch]158-scotch and [I]0-i could pass anywhere as [an ordinary Scotsman]459-an ordinary scotsman . [I]0-i had half an idea at first to be [a German tourist]460-a german tourist , for [[my]0-i father]244-my father had had [German partners]462-german partners , and [I]0-i had been brought up to speak the tongue pretty fluently , not to mention having put in three years prospecting for copper in [German Damaraland]41-german damaraland . But [I]0-i calculated that it would be less conspicuous to be [a Scot]463-a scot , and less in a line with what [the police]1436-the police might know of [my]0-i past . [I]0-i fixed on [Galloway]42-galloway as [the best place to go]465-the best place to go . [It]42-galloway was [the nearest wild part of [Scotland]3-scotland]466-the nearest wild part of scotland , so far as [I]0-i could figure it out , and from the look of the map was not over thick with population . A search in [Bradshaw]43-bradshaw informed [me]0-i that [a train]467-a train left [St Pancras]44-st pancras at 7.10 , which would land [me]0-i at [any [Galloway]42-galloway station]468-any galloway station in the late afternoon . That was well enough , but a more important matter was how [I]0-i was to make [my]0-i way to [St Pancras]44-st pancras , for [I]0-i was pretty certain that [[Scudder]148-scudder 's friends]469-scudder 's friends would be watching outside . This puzzled [me]0-i for a bit ; then [I]0-i had an inspiration , on which [I]0-i went to bed and slept for two troubled hours . [I]0-i got up at four and opened [my]0-i bedroom shutters . The faint light of a fine summer morning was flooding the skies , and the sparrows had begun to chatter . [I]0-i had a great revulsion of feeling , and felt [a God - forgotten fool]470-a god - forgotten fool . [My]0-i inclination was to let things slide , and trust to [the British police]471-the british police taking a reasonable view of [my]0-i case . But as [I]0-i reviewed the situation [I]0-i could find no arguments to bring against [my]0-i decision of the previous night , so with a wry mouth [I]0-i resolved to go on with [my]0-i plan . [I]0-i was not feeling in any particular funk ; only disinclined to go looking for trouble , if [you]472-you understand [me]0-i . [I]0-i hunted out a well - used tweed suit , a pair of strong nailed boots , and a flannel shirt with a collar . Into [my]0-i pockets [I]0-i stuffed a spare shirt , a cloth cap , some handkerchiefs , and a tooth - brush . [I]0-i had drawn a good sum in gold from [the bank]473-the bank two days before , in case [Scudder]148-scudder should want money , and [I]0-i took fifty pounds of it in sovereigns in a belt which [I]0-i had brought back from [Rhodesia]45-rhodesia . That was about all [I]0-i wanted . Then [I]0-i had a bath , and cut [my]0-i moustache , which was long and drooping , into a short stubbly fringe . Now came the next step . [Paddock]151-paddock used to arrive punctually at 7.30 and let [himself]151-paddock in with a latch - key . But about twenty minutes to seven , as [I]0-i knew from bitter experience , [the milkman]474-the milkman turned up with a great clatter of cans , and deposited [my]0-i share outside [my]0-i door . [I]0-i had seen [that milkman]475-that milkman sometimes when [I]0-i had gone out for an early ride . [He]475-that milkman was [a young man about [my]0-i own height , with an ill - nourished moustache]476-a young man about my own height , with an ill - nourished moustache , and [he]475-that milkman wore a white overall . On [him]475-that milkman [I]0-i staked all [my]0-i chances . [I]0-i went into [the darkened smoking - room]477-the darkened smoking - room where the rays of morning light were beginning to creep through the shutters . There [I]0-i breakfasted off a whisky - and - soda and some biscuits from the cupboard . By this time it was getting on for six o'clock . [I]0-i put a pipe in [my]0-i pocket and filled [my]0-i pouch from the tobacco jar on the table by the fireplace . As [I]0-i poked into the tobacco [my]0-i fingers touched something hard , and [I]0-i drew out [Scudder]148-scudder 's little black pocket - book ... That seemed to [me]0-i a good omen . [I]0-i lifted the cloth from the body and was amazed at the peace and dignity of the dead face . ' Goodbye , [old chap]1492-old chap , '[0-i] [I]0-i said ; ' [I]0-i am going to do [my]0-i best for [you]1492-old chap . Wish [me]0-i well , wherever [you]1492-old chap are . '[0-i] Then [I]0-i hung about in [the hall]478-the hall waiting for [the milkman]474-the milkman . That was the worst part of the business , for [I]0-i was fairly choking to get out of doors . Six - thirty passed , then six - forty , but still [he]474-the milkman did not come . [The fool]480-the fool had chosen this day of all days to be late . At one minute after the quarter to seven [I]0-i heard the rattle of the cans outside . [I]0-i opened the front door , and there was [[my]0-i man]377-my man , singling out [my]0-i cans from a bunch [he]377-my man carried and whistling through [his]377-my man teeth . [He]377-my man jumped a bit at the sight of [me]0-i . ' Come in [here]1478-here a moment , '[0-i] [I]0-i said . ' [I]0-i want a word with [you]377-my man . '[0-i] And [I]0-i led [him]377-my man into [the dining - room]454-the dining - room . ' [I]0-i reckon [you]377-my man 're[0-i] [a bit of a sportsman]483-a bit of a sportsman , ' [I]483-a bit of a sportsman said , '[483-a bit of a sportsman] and [I]0-i want [you]377-my man to do [me]0-i a service . ' [His]377-my man eyes opened at the sight of the gold , and [he]377-my man grinned broadly . '[483-a bit of a sportsman] Wot 's the gyme?'he asked . ' A bet , '[0-i] [I]0-i said . ' [I]0-i have n't time to explain , but to win it [I]0-i 've got to be [a milkman]1494-a milkman for the next ten minutes . ' [I]484-guv'nor stuck on [his]377-my man flat blue hat and [his]377-my man white overall , picked up the cans , banged [my]484-guv'nor door , and went whistling [downstairs]1498-downstairs . [The porter at the foot]1499-the porter at the foot told [me]484-guv'nor to shut [my]484-guv'nor jaw , which sounded as if [my]484-guv'nor make - up was adequate . At first [I]484-guv'nor thought there was [nobody]1477-nobody in [the street]1452-the street . As [the loafer]1505-the loafer passed [he]377-my man looked up , and [I]484-guv'nor fancied a signal was exchanged . Then [I]484-guv'nor took [the first side street]1508-the first side street , and went up a left - hand turning which led past a bit of vacant ground . There was [no one]1509-no one in [the little street]1510-the little street , so [I]484-guv'nor dropped the milk - cans inside the hoarding and sent the cap and overall after [them]474-the milkman . [I]484-guv'nor had only just put on [my]484-guv'nor cloth cap when [a postman]1511-a postman came round the corner . [I]484-guv'nor gave [him]1511-a postman good morning and [he]1511-a postman answered [me]484-guv'nor unsuspiciously . At the moment the clock of [a neighbouring church]1512-a neighbouring church struck the hour of seven . There was not a second to spare . As soon as [I]484-guv'nor got to [Euston Road]1513-euston road [I]484-guv'nor took to [my]484-guv'nor heels and ran . The clock at [Euston Station]46-euston station showed five minutes past the hour . At [St Pancras]44-st pancras [I]484-guv'nor had no time to take a ticket , let alone that [I]484-guv'nor had not settled upon [my]484-guv'nor destination . [A porter]289-a porter told [me]484-guv'nor [the platform]1515-the platform , and as [I]484-guv'nor entered [it]1515-the platform [I]484-guv'nor saw [the train]1516-the train already in motion . [[Two station]1517-two station officials]1518-two station officials blocked the way , but [I]484-guv'nor dodged [them]1518-two station officials and clambered into [the last carriage]1519-the last carriage . [He]289-a porter went off grumbling , and as [I]484-guv'nor mopped [my]484-guv'nor brow [I]484-guv'nor observed to [[my]484-guv'nor companions]1528-my companions in [my]484-guv'nor broadest Scots that it was a sore job catching trains . [I]484-guv'nor had already entered upon [my]484-guv'nor part . '[484-guv'nor] The impidence o ' that gyaird ! '[485-the lady] said [the lady]485-the lady bitterly . ' [He]487-i needit a Scotch tongue to pit [him]487-i in [his]487-i place . [He]487-i was complainin '[485-the lady] o ' this wean no haein '[484-guv'nor] a ticket and [her]486-her no fower till [August twalmonth]160-august twalmonth , and [he]487-i was objectin ' to [this gentleman]1529-this gentleman spittin '[487-i] . ' [The sailor]1530-the sailor morosely agreed , and [I]487-i started [my]487-i new life in an atmosphere of protest against authority . [I]487-i reminded [myself]487-i that a week ago [I]487-i had been finding [the world]309-the world dull . [I]487-i had a solemn time travelling north that day . It was fine May weather , with the hawthorn flowering on every hedge , and [I]487-i asked [myself]487-i why , when [I]487-i was still [a free man]1532-a free man , [I]487-i had stayed on in [London]1-london and not got the good of [this heavenly country]1533-this heavenly country . [I]487-i did n't dare face [the restaurant car]1534-the restaurant car , but [I]487-i got a luncheon - basket at [Leeds]48-leeds and shared it with [the fat woman]1535-the fat woman . Also [I]487-i got the morning 's papers , with news about starters for the Derby and the beginning of the cricket season , and some paragraphs about how [Balkan]49-balkan affairs were settling down and [a British squadron]1536-a british squadron was going to [Kiel]50-kiel . When [I]487-i had done with [them]1537-them [I]487-i got out [Scudder]148-scudder 's little black pocket - book and studied it . It was pretty well filled with jottings , chiefly figures , though now and then a name was printed in . For example , [I]487-i found the words '[487-i] Hofgaard ' , '[485-the lady] [Luneville]51-luneville ' , and '[485-the lady] Avocado ' pretty often , and especially the word '[485-the lady] Pavia ' . Now [I]485-the lady was certain that [Scudder]148-scudder never did anything without a reason , and [I]485-the lady was pretty sure that there was a cypher in all this . That is a subject which has always interested [me]485-the lady , and [I]485-the lady did a bit at it [myself]485-the lady once as [intelligence officer at [Delagoa Bay]52-delagoa bay]1538-intelligence officer at delagoa bay during the Boer War . [I]485-the lady have a head for things like chess and puzzles , and [I]485-the lady used to reckon [myself]485-the lady pretty good at finding out cyphers . This one looked like the numerical kind where sets of figures correspond to the letters of the alphabet , but [any fairly shrewd man]1539-any fairly shrewd man can find the clue to that sort after an hour or two 's work , and [I]485-the lady did n't think [Scudder]148-scudder would have been content with anything so easy . So [I]485-the lady fastened on the printed words , for [you]1540-you can make a pretty good numerical cypher if [you]1540-you have a key word which gives [you]1540-you the sequence of the letters . [I]485-the lady tried for hours , but none of the words answered . Then [I]485-the lady fell asleep and woke at [Dumfries]53-dumfries just in time to bundle out and get into [the slow Galloway train]1541-the slow galloway train . There was [a man on [the platform]1515-the platform whose looks [I]485-the lady did n't like]1542-a man on the platform whose looks i did n't like , but [he]1542-a man on the platform whose looks i did n't like never glanced at [me]485-the lady , and when [I]485-the lady caught sight of [myself]485-the lady in the mirror of an automatic machine [I]485-the lady did n't wonder . With [my]485-the lady brown face , [my]485-the lady old tweeds , and [my]485-the lady slouch , [I]485-the lady was the very model of [one of [the hill farmers who were crowding into [the third - class carriages]1546-the third - class carriages]1545-the hill farmers who were crowding into the third - class carriages]1544-one of the hill farmers who were crowding into the third - class carriages . [I]485-the lady travelled with half a dozen in an atmosphere of shag and clay pipes . [They]1547-they had come from the weekly market , and [their]1547-they mouths were full of prices . [I]485-the lady heard accounts of how the lambing had gone up [the Cairn]1548-the cairn and [the Deuch]54-the deuch and a dozen other mysterious waters . Above half [the men]1549-the men had lunched heavily and were highly flavoured with whisky , but [they]1547-they took no notice of [me]485-the lady . [We]1550-we rumbled slowly into [a land of [little wooded glens]1552-little wooded glens]1551-a land of little wooded glens and then to [a great wide moorland place , gleaming with [lochs , with high blue hills]1554-lochs , with high blue hills showing northwards]1553-a great wide moorland place , gleaming with lochs , with high blue hills showing northwards . About five o'clock [the carriage]1555-the carriage had emptied , and [I]485-the lady was left alone as [I]485-the lady had hoped . [I]485-the lady got out at [the next station]1556-the next station , [a little place whose name [I]485-the lady scarcely noted , set right in [the heart of a bog]1558-the heart of a bog]1557-a little place whose name i scarcely noted , set right in the heart of a bog . [It]1556-the next station reminded [me]485-the lady of [one of [those forgotten little stations in [the Karroo]55-the karroo]1560-those forgotten little stations in the karroo]1559-one of those forgotten little stations in the karroo . [An old station - master]1561-an old station - master was digging in [[his]1561-an old station - master garden]1562-his garden , and with [his]1561-an old station - master spade over [his]1561-an old station - master shoulder sauntered to [the train]1516-the train , took charge of a parcel , and went back to [[his]1561-an old station - master potatoes]1564-his potatoes . [A child of ten]1565-a child of ten received [my]485-the lady ticket , and [I]485-the lady emerged on [a white road]1566-a white road that straggled over [the brown moor]1567-the brown moor . It was a gorgeous spring evening , with [every hill]1568-every hill showing as clear as a cut amethyst . The air had the queer , rooty smell of bogs , but it was as fresh as mid - ocean , and it had the strangest effect on [my]485-the lady spirits . [I]485-the lady actually felt light - hearted . [I]485-the lady might have been [a boy out for a spring holiday tramp]1569-a boy out for a spring holiday tramp , instead of [a man of thirty - seven very much wanted by the police]1570-a man of thirty - seven very much wanted by the police . [I]485-the lady felt just as [I]485-the lady used to feel when [I]485-the lady was starting for a big trek on a frosty morning on [the high veld]1571-the high veld . If [you]1572-you believe [me]485-the lady , [I]485-the lady swung along [that road]1573-that road whistling . There was no plan of campaign in [my]485-the lady head , only just to go on and on in [this blessed , honest - smelling hill country]1574-this blessed , honest - smelling hill country , for every mile put [me]485-the lady in better humour with [myself]485-the lady . In [a roadside planting]1575-a roadside planting [I]485-the lady cut a walking - stick of hazel , and presently struck off [the highway]1576-the highway up a bypath which followed [the glen of [a brawling stream]1578-a brawling stream]1577-the glen of a brawling stream . [I]485-the lady reckoned that [I]485-the lady was still far ahead of any pursuit , and for that night might please [myself]485-the lady . It was some hours since [I]485-the lady had tasted food , and [I]485-the lady was getting very hungry when [I]485-the lady came to [a herd 's cottage set in a nook beside [a waterfall]1580-a waterfall]1579-a herd 's cottage set in a nook beside a waterfall . [A brown - faced woman]1581-a brown - faced woman was standing by the door , and greeted [me]485-the lady with the kindly shyness of [moorland places]1582-moorland places . When [I]485-the lady asked for a night 's lodging [she]1581-a brown - faced woman said [I]485-the lady was welcome to the '[485-the lady] bed in [the loft]488-the loft ' , and very soon [she]1581-a brown - faced woman set before [me]485-the lady a hearty meal of ham and eggs , scones , and thick sweet milk . At the darkening [[her]1581-a brown - faced woman man]1583-her man came in from [the hills]1584-the hills , [a lean giant , who in one step covered as much ground as three paces of [ordinary mortals]1586-ordinary mortals]1585-a lean giant , who in one step covered as much ground as three paces of ordinary mortals . [They]1584-the hills asked [me]485-the lady no questions , for [they]1584-the hills had the perfect breeding of [all dwellers in [the wilds]1588-the wilds]1587-all dwellers in the wilds , but [I]485-the lady could see [they]1584-the hills set [me]485-the lady down as [a kind of dealer]1589-a kind of dealer , and [I]485-the lady took some trouble to confirm [their]1584-the hills view . [I]485-the lady spoke a lot about cattle , of which [[my]485-the lady host]1590-my host knew little , and [I]485-the lady picked up from [him]1590-my host a good deal about [the local Galloway markets]1591-the local galloway markets , which [I]485-the lady tucked away in [my]485-the lady memory for future use . At ten [I]485-the lady was nodding in [my]485-the lady chair , and the '[485-the lady] bed in [the loft]488-the loft ' received [a weary man who never opened [his]1592-a weary man who never opened his eyes till five o'clock set the little homestead a - going once more eyes till five o'clock set [the little homestead]1593-the little homestead a - going once more]1592-a weary man who never opened his eyes till five o'clock set the little homestead a - going once more . [They]1584-the hills refused any payment , and by six [I]485-the lady had breakfasted and was striding southwards again . [My]485-the lady notion was to return to [the railway line]1594-the railway line [a station]1595-a station or two farther on than [the place where [I]485-the lady had alighted yesterday and to double back]1596-the place where i had alighted yesterday and to double back . [I]485-the lady reckoned that that was the safest way , for [the police]1436-the police would naturally assume that [I]485-the lady was always making farther from [London]1-london in [the direction of [some western port]1599-some western port]1598-the direction of some western port . [I]485-the lady thought [I]485-the lady had still a good bit of a start , for , as [I]485-the lady reasoned , it would take some hours to fix the blame on [me]485-the lady , and several more to identify [the fellow who got on board [the train]1516-the train at [St Pancras]44-st pancras]1600-the fellow who got on board the train at st pancras . It was the same jolly , clear spring weather , and [I]485-the lady simply could not contrive to feel careworn . Indeed [I]485-the lady was in better spirits than [I]485-the lady had been for months . Over [a long ridge of moorland]1602-a long ridge of moorland [I]485-the lady took [[my]485-the lady road]1603-my road , skirting the side of a high hill which the herd had called [[Cairnsmore]56-cairnsmore of [Fleet]57-fleet]1604-cairnsmore of fleet . Nesting curlews and plovers were crying everywhere , and the links of green pasture by [the streams]1605-the streams were dotted with young lambs . All the slackness of the past months was slipping from [my]485-the lady bones , and [I]485-the lady stepped out like [a four - year - old]1606-a four - year - old . So [I]0-i opened the door , and dropped quickly into the tangle of hazels which edged the line . It would have been all right but for that infernal dog . Under the impression that [I]0-i was decamping with [its master]1664-its master 's belongings , it started to bark , and all but got [me]0-i by the trousers . This woke up the herd , who stood bawling at the carriage door in the belief that [I]0-i had committed suicide . [I]0-i crawled through the thicket , reached [the edge of [the stream]1666-the stream]1665-the edge of the stream , and in cover of the bushes put a hundred yards or so behind [me]0-i . Presently [they]1671-their had forgotten [me]0-i , and when after a quarter of a mile 's crawl [I]0-i ventured to look back , [the train]1516-the train had started again and was vanishing in the cutting . [I]0-i was in [a wide semicircle of moorland]1677-a wide semicircle of moorland , with [the brown river]1678-the brown river as radius , and [the high hills forming the northern circumference]1679-the high hills forming the northern circumference . [I]0-i looked back , but there was nothing in [the landscape]1663-the landscape . Then it seemed to change its mind , rose to a great height , and flew away back to the south . [I]0-i did not like this espionage from the air , and [I]0-i began to think less well of [the countryside [I]0-i had chosen for a refuge]1702-the countryside i had chosen for a refuge . [I]153-julia czechenyi got rid of [the innkeeper]1767-the innkeeper for the afternoon , for [I]153-julia czechenyi was getting very warm in [my]153-julia czechenyi search for the cypher . As [I]153-julia czechenyi told [you]1775-you , it was a numerical cypher , and by an elaborate system of experiments [I]153-julia czechenyi had pretty well discovered what were the nulls and stops . The trouble was the key word , and when [I]153-julia czechenyi thought of the odd million words [he]148-scudder might have used [I]153-julia czechenyi felt pretty hopeless . But about three o'clock [I]153-julia czechenyi had a sudden inspiration . The name [Julia Czechenyi]153-julia czechenyi flashed across [my]153-julia czechenyi memory . [Scudder]148-scudder had said it was the key to the Karolides business , and it occurred to [me]153-julia czechenyi to try it on [his]148-scudder cypher . It worked . The five letters of '[153-julia czechenyi] [Julia]153-julia czechenyi ' gave [me]153-julia czechenyi the position of the vowels . A was J , the tenth letter of the alphabet , and so represented by X in the cypher . E was XXI , and so on . '[153-julia czechenyi] [Czechenyi]153-julia czechenyi ' gave [me]153-julia czechenyi the numerals for the principal consonants . [I]153-julia czechenyi scribbled that scheme on a bit of paper and sat down to read [Scudder]148-scudder 's pages . [Scudder]148-scudder had got on to this , but [he]148-scudder could not act for a fortnight . '[0-i] [I]0-i manufactured it rather neatly , so that it looked like a loose page of a private letter . ' Take this down and say it was found in [[my]0-i bedroom]1466-my bedroom , and ask [them]515-the two figures to return it to [me]0-i if [they]515-the two figures overtake [me]0-i . '[0-i] Three minutes later [I]0-i heard [the car]514-the car begin to move , and peeping from behind the curtain caught sight of [the two figures]515-the two figures . When [he]519-he went to bed [I]0-i sat up and finished [Scudder]148-scudder . [I]0-i smoked in a chair till daylight , for [I]0-i could not sleep . About eight next morning [I]0-i witnessed the arrival of [two constables]522-two constables and [a sergeant]523-a sergeant . [They]522-two constables put [[their]522-two constables car]524-their car in [a coach - house]525-a coach - house under [the innkeeper]1767-the innkeeper 's instructions , and entered [the house]1720-the house . A minute or two later [I]0-i heard [their]522-two constables steps on the gravel outside the window . [My]0-i plan had been to lie hid in [[my]0-i bedroom]1466-my bedroom , and see what happened . [I]0-i had a notion that , if [I]0-i could bring [the police]1436-the police and [[my]0-i other more dangerous pursuers]535-my other more dangerous pursuers together , something might work out of it to [my]0-i advantage . But now [I]0-i had a better idea . [I]0-i scribbled a line of thanks to [[my]0-i host]1590-my host , opened the window , and dropped quietly into a gooseberry bush . Unobserved [I]0-i crossed [the dyke]537-the dyke , crawled down the side of [a tributary burn]538-a tributary burn , and won the highroad on [the far side of [the patch of trees]540-the patch of trees]539-the far side of the patch of trees . There stood [the car]514-the car , very spick and span in the morning sunlight , but with the dust on [her]514-the car which told of a long journey . [I]0-i started [her]514-the car , jumped into the chauffeur 's seat , and stole gently out on to [the plateau]542-the plateau . Almost at once [the road]1715-the road dipped so that [I]0-i lost sight of [the inn]500-the inn , but the wind seemed to bring [me]0-i the sound of angry voices . [You]545-you may picture [me]0-i driving [that 40 h.p . car]546-that 40 h.p . car for all [she]514-the car was worth over the crisp moor roads on that shining May morning ; glancing back at first over [my]0-i shoulder , and looking anxiously to the next turning ; then driving with a vague eye , just wide enough awake to keep on [the highway]1576-the highway . For [I]0-i was thinking desperately of what [I]0-i had found in [Scudder]148-scudder 's pocket - book . [The little man]548-the little man had told [me]0-i a pack of lies . All [his]548-the little man yarns about [the Balkans]169-the balkans and [the Jew - Anarchists]549-the jew - anarchists and [the Foreign Office Conference]550-the foreign office conference were eyewash , and so was [Karolides]141-karolides . And yet not quite , as [you]545-you shall hear . [I]0-i had staked everything on [my]0-i belief in [his]548-the little man story , and had been let down ; here was [his]548-the little man book telling [me]0-i a different tale , and instead of being once - bitten - twice - shy , [I]0-i believed it absolutely . Why , [I]0-i do n't know . It rang desperately true , and the first yarn , if [you]545-you understand [me]0-i , had been in a queer way true also in spirit . The fifteenth day of June was going to be a day of destiny , a bigger destiny than the killing of [a Dago]170-a dago . It was so big that [I]0-i did n't blame [Scudder]148-scudder for keeping [me]0-i out of the game and wanting to play a lone hand . That , [I]0-i was pretty clear , was [his]148-scudder intention . [He]148-scudder had told [me]0-i something which sounded big enough , but the real thing was so immortally big that [he]148-scudder , [the man who had found it out]551-the man who had found it out , wanted it all for [himself]148-scudder . [I]0-i did n't blame [him]148-scudder . It was risks after all that [he]148-scudder was chiefly greedy about . The whole story was in the notes - with gaps , [you]545-you understand , which [he]148-scudder would have filled up from [his]148-scudder memory . [He]148-scudder stuck down [[his]148-scudder authorities]552-his authorities , too , and had an odd trick of giving [them]552-his authorities all a numerical value and then striking a balance , which stood for the reliability of each stage in the yarn . The four names [he]148-scudder had printed were [authorities]553-authorities , and there was [a man , [Ducrosne]171-ducrosne , who got five out of a possible five]554-a man , ducrosne , who got five out of a possible five ; and another fellow , [Ammersfoort]172-ammersfoort , who got three . The bare bones of the tale were all that was in the book - these , and one queer phrase which occurred half a dozen times inside brackets . ' ( Thirty - nine steps ) '[171-ducrosne] was the phrase ; and at its last time of use it ran-'(Thirty - nine steps , [I]0-i counted them - high tide 10.17 p.m. ) ' . [I]9-berlin could make nothing of that . The first thing [I]9-berlin learned was that it was no question of preventing a war . That was coming , as sure as Christmas : had been arranged , said [Scudder]148-scudder , ever since February 1912 . [Karolides]141-karolides was going to be the occasion . [He]148-scudder was booked all right , and was to hand in [his]148-scudder checks on June 14th , two weeks and four days from that May morning . [I]9-berlin gathered from [Scudder]148-scudder 's notes that nothing on [earth]1797-earth could prevent that . [His]148-scudder talk of [Epirote guards that would skin [[their]1798-epirote guards that would skin their own grandmothers own grandmothers]1799-their own grandmothers]1798-epirote guards that would skin their own grandmothers was all billy - o. The second thing was that this war was going to come as a mighty surprise to [Britain]69-britain . [Karolides]141-karolides '[9-berlin] death would set [the Balkans]169-the balkans by the ears , and then [Vienna]10-vienna would chip in with an ultimatum . [Russia]21-russia would n't like that , and there would be high words . But [Berlin]9-berlin would play [the peacemaker]555-the peacemaker , and pour oil on the waters , till suddenly [she]9-berlin would find a good cause for a quarrel , pick it up , and in five hours let fly at [us]556-us . That was the idea , and a pretty good one too . Honey and fair speeches , and then a stroke in the dark . While [we]556-us were talking about the goodwill and good intentions of [Germany]22-germany [[our]556-us coast]557-our coast would be silently ringed with mines , and [submarines]558-submarines would be waiting for [every battleship]559-every battleship . But all this depended upon the third thing , which was due to happen on June 15th . [I]0-i would never have grasped this if [I]0-i had n't once happened to meet [a French staff officer]560-a french staff officer , coming back from [West Africa]70-west africa , who had told [me]0-i a lot of things . One was that , in spite of all the nonsense talked in Parliament , there was a real working alliance between [France]71-france and [Britain]69-britain , and that [the two General Staffs]561-the two general staffs met every now and then , and made plans for joint action in case of war . Well , in June a very great swell was coming over from [Paris]30-paris , and [he]560-a french staff officer was going to get nothing less than a statement of the disposition of [the British Home Fleet]562-the british home fleet on mobilization . At least [I]0-i gathered it was something like that ; anyhow , it was something uncommonly important . But on the 15th day of June there were to be others in [London]1-london - others , at whom [I]0-i could only guess . [Scudder]148-scudder was content to call [them]563-them collectively the ' Black Stone '[148-scudder] . [They]563-them represented not [[our]564-our Allies]565-our allies , but [[our]564-our deadly foes]566-our deadly foes ; and the information , destined for [France]71-france , was to be diverted to [their]563-them pockets . And it was to be used , remember - used a week or two later , with great guns and swift torpedoes , suddenly in the darkness of a summer night . This was the story [I]0-i had been deciphering in [a back room of [a country inn]568-a country inn , overlooking [a cabbage garden]569-a cabbage garden]567-a back room of a country inn , overlooking a cabbage garden . This was the story that hummed in [my]0-i brain as [I]0-i swung in [the big touring - car]570-the big touring - car from [glen to glen]571-glen to glen . [My]0-i first impulse had been to write a letter to [the Prime Minister]1479-the prime minister , but a little reflection convinced [me]0-i that that would be useless . Who would believe [my]0-i tale ? [I]0-i must show a sign , some token in proof , and [Heaven]156-heaven knew what that could be . Above all , [I]0-i must keep going [myself]0-i , ready to act when things got riper , and that was going to be no light job with [the police of [the British Isles]40-the british isles]573-the police of the british isles in full cry after [me]0-i and [the watchers of the Black Stone]574-the watchers of the black stone running silently and swiftly on [my]0-i trail . [I]0-i had no very clear purpose in [my]0-i journey , but [I]0-i steered east by the sun , for [I]0-i remembered from the map that if [I]0-i went [north]1773-north [I]0-i would come into [a region of coalpits and [industrial towns]577-industrial towns]576-a region of coalpits and industrial towns . But there [I]0-i was mistaken . [[My]0-i car]633-my car slithered through the hedge like butter , and then gave a sickening plunge forward . [I]0-i saw what was coming , leapt on the seat and would have jumped out . But a branch of hawthorn got [me]0-i in the chest , lifted [me]0-i up and held [me]0-i , while a ton or two of expensive metal slipped below [me]0-i , bucked and pitched , and then dropped with an almighty smash fifty feet to the bed of [the stream]1666-the stream . Slowly that thorn let [me]0-i go . [I]0-i subsided first on the hedge , and then very gently on a bower of nettles . As [I]0-i scrambled to [my]0-i feet a hand took [me]0-i by the arm , and a sympathetic and badly scared voice asked [me]0-i if [I]0-i were hurt . '[0-i] [I]0-i 'm not much good as [a speaker]1819-a speaker , but [I]0-i 'll tell [them]1820-them a bit about [Australia]74-australia . '[0-i] At [my]0-i words the cares of the ages slipped from [his]0-i shoulders , and [he]0-i was rapturous in [his]0-i thanks . [He]0-i lent [me]0-i a big driving coat - and never troubled to ask why [I]0-i had started on a motor tour without possessing an ulster - and , as [we]653-we slipped down [the dusty roads]654-the dusty roads , poured into [my]0-i ears the simple facts of [his]0-i history . [He]0-i was [an orphan]655-an orphan , and [[his]0-i uncle]656-his uncle had brought [him]0-i up - [I've]0-i forgotten [the uncle]657-the uncle 's name , but [he]0-i was in [the Cabinet]658-the cabinet , and [you]659-you can read [his]0-i speeches in the papers . [He]0-i had gone round [the world]309-the world after leaving [Cambridge]75-cambridge , and then , being short of a job , [[his]0-i uncle]656-his uncle had advised politics . [I]0-i gathered that [he]0-i had no preference in parties . ' [Good chaps]1821-good chaps in both , '[0-i] [he]0-i said cheerfully , ' and plenty of [blighters]1822-blighters , too . [I]0-i 'm[0-i] Liberal , because [[my]0-i family]662-my family have always been [Whigs]663-whigs . ' But if [he]0-i was lukewarm politically [he]0-i had strong views on other things . [He]0-i found out [I]0-i knew a bit about horses , and jawed away about the Derby entries ; and [he]0-i was full of plans for improving [his]0-i shooting . [Altogether]176-altogether , [a very clean , decent , callow young man]1823-a very clean , decent , callow young man . '[0-i] Beg pardon , [Sir Harry]177-sir harry , ' said [one]408-one . '[177-sir harry] [We]664-we 've got instructions to look out for [a car]632-a car , and the description 's no unlike [yours]177-sir harry . ' '[177-sir harry] Right - o , ' said [[my]177-sir harry host]1590-my host , while [I]177-sir harry thanked [Providence]178-providence for the devious ways [I]177-sir harry had been brought to safety . After that [he]0-i spoke no more , for [his]0-i mind began to labour heavily with [his]0-i coming speech . [His]0-i lips kept muttering , [his]0-i eye wandered , and [I]177-sir harry began to prepare [myself]177-sir harry for a second catastrophe . [I]177-sir harry tried to think of something to say [myself]177-sir harry , but [my]177-sir harry mind was dry as a stone . The next thing [I]177-sir harry knew [we]664-we had drawn up outside a door in [a street]1828-a street , and were being welcomed by [some noisy gentlemen with rosettes]1829-some noisy gentlemen with rosettes . [The hall]478-the hall had about five hundred in [it]478-the hall , [women]1831-women mostly , a lot of bald heads , and [a dozen or two young men]1832-a dozen or two young men . [The chairman]1833-the chairman , [a weaselly minister with a reddish nose]1834-a weaselly minister with a reddish nose , lamented [Crumpleton]175-crumpleton 's absence , soliloquized on [his]1833-the chairman influenza , and gave [me]177-sir harry a certificate as [a '[177-sir harry] trusted leader of Australian thought ']1835-a ' trusted leader of australian thought ' . Then [Sir Harry]177-sir harry started . [I]177-sir harry never heard anything like it . [He]177-sir harry did n't begin to know how to talk . [He]177-sir harry had about a bushel of notes from which [he]177-sir harry read , and when [he]177-sir harry let go of them [he]177-sir harry fell into one prolonged stutter . Every now and then [he]177-sir harry remembered a phrase [he]177-sir harry had learned by heart , straightened [his]177-sir harry back , and gave it off like [Henry Irving]179-henry irving , and the next moment [he]177-sir harry was bent double and crooning over [his]177-sir harry papers . It was the most appalling rot , too . [He]177-sir harry talked about the '[177-sir harry] German menace ' , and said it was all [a Tory invention]1837-a tory invention to cheat [the poor]1838-the poor of [their]1838-the poor rights and keep back the great flood of social reform , but that '[177-sir harry] organized labour ' realized this and laughed [the Tories]1839-the tories to scorn . [He]177-sir harry was all for reducing [our]1840-our Navy as a proof of [our]1840-our good faith , and then sending [Germany]22-germany an ultimatum telling [her]22-germany to do the same or [we]1840-our would knock [her]22-germany into a cocked hat . [You]1844-you could see the niceness of the chap shining out behind the muck with which [he]177-sir harry had been spoon - fed . Also it took a load off [my]177-sir harry mind . [I]177-sir harry might n't be much of [an orator]1845-an orator , but [I]177-sir harry was a thousand per cent better than [Sir Harry]177-sir harry . At two o'clock [he]681-me wakened [me]0-i from [my]0-i slumbers in the smoking - room armchair , and led [me]0-i blinking into the dark starry night . ' First turn to the right up by [the long fir - wood]1877-the long fir - wood , '[681-me] [he]681-me enjoined . ' By daybreak [you]0-i 'll be well into [the hills]1584-the hills . [You]0-i can put in a week among [the shepherds]1881-the shepherds , and be as safe as if [you]0-i were in [New Guinea]79-new guinea . '[681-me] [I]0-i pedalled diligently up [steep roads of]686-steep roads of [hill gravel]687-hill gravel till the skies grew pale with morning . As the mists cleared before the sun , [I]0-i found [myself]0-i in [a wide green world with glens falling on every side and a far - away blue horizon]688-a wide green world with glens falling on every side and a far - away blue horizon . [I]0-i sat down on [the very crest of [the pass]691-the pass]690-the very crest of the pass and took stock of [my]0-i position . Behind [me]0-i was [the road]1715-the road climbing through a long cleft in [the hills]1584-the hills , which was [the upper glen of some notable river]694-the upper glen of some notable river . In front was a flat space of maybe a mile , all pitted with [bog - holes and rough with tussocks]695-bog - holes and rough with tussocks , and then beyond it [the road]1715-the road fell steeply down [another glen]697-another glen to [a plain]698-a plain whose blue dimness melted into the distance . To left and right were round - shouldered green hills as smooth as pancakes , but to the south - that is , the left hand - there was a glimpse of [high heathery mountains]699-high heathery mountains , which [I]0-i remembered from the map as the big knot of hill which [I]0-i had chosen for [[my]0-i sanctuary]700-my sanctuary . [I]0-i was on [the central boss of [a huge upland country]702-a huge upland country]701-the central boss of a huge upland country , and could see everything moving for miles . In the meadows below [the road]1715-the road half a mile back [a cottage]704-a cottage smoked , but it was the only sign of human life . Otherwise there was only the calling of plovers and the tinkling of little streams . It was now about seven o'clock , and as [I]0-i waited [I]0-i heard once again that ominous beat in the air . Then [I]0-i realized that [my]0-i vantage - ground might be in reality a trap . There was no cover for a tomtit in [those bald green places]705-those bald green places . [I]0-i sat quite still and hopeless while the beat grew louder . Then [I]0-i saw [an aeroplane]706-an aeroplane coming up from [the east]707-the east . [It]706-an aeroplane was flying high , but as [I]0-i looked it dropped several hundred feet and began to circle round the knot of hill in narrowing circles , just as a hawk wheels before it pounces . Now it was flying very low , and now [the observer on board]708-the observer on board caught sight of [me]0-i . [I]0-i could see one of [the two occupants]709-the two occupants examining [me]0-i through glasses . Suddenly it began to rise in swift whorls , and the next [I]0-i knew [it]706-an aeroplane was speeding eastward again till it became a speck in the blue morning . That made [me]0-i do some savage thinking . [[My]0-i enemies]1704-my enemies had located [me]0-i , and the next thing would be a cordon round [me]0-i . [I]0-i did n't know what force [they]1704-my enemies could command , but [I]0-i was certain it would be sufficient . [The aeroplane]622-the aeroplane had seen [[my]0-i bicycle]712-my bicycle , and would conclude that [I]0-i would try to escape by [the road]1715-the road . In that case there might be a chance on [the moors]1880-the moors to the right or left . [I]0-i wheeled the machine a hundred yards from [the highway]1576-the highway , and plunged it into [a moss - hole]716-a moss - hole , where it sank among pond - weed and water - buttercups . Then [I]0-i climbed to a knoll which gave [me]0-i a view of [the two valleys]717-the two valleys . Nothing was stirring on the long white ribbon that threaded them . [I]0-i have said there was not cover in [the whole place]1813-the whole place to hide a rat . As the day advanced [it]1813-the whole place was flooded with soft fresh light till [it]1813-the whole place had the fragrant sunniness of [the South African veld]80-the south african veld . At other times [I]0-i would have liked [the place]380-the place , but now it seemed to suffocate [me]0-i . [The free moorlands]720-the free moorlands were prison walls , and the keen hill air was the breath of a dungeon . [I]0-i tossed a coin - heads right , tails left - and it fell heads , so [I]0-i turned to the north . In a little [I]0-i came to the brow of [the ridge which was the containing wall of [the pass]691-the pass]721-the ridge which was the containing wall of the pass . [I]0-i saw [the highroad]723-the highroad for maybe ten miles , and far down [it]723-the highroad something that was moving , and that [I]0-i took to be [a motor - car]724-a motor - car . Beyond [the ridge]1695-the ridge [I]0-i looked on [a rolling green moor]726-a rolling green moor , which fell away into [wooded glens]727-wooded glens . Now [my]0-i life on [the veld]254-the veld has given [me]0-i the eyes of a kite , and [I]0-i can see things for which [most men]729-most men need a telescope ... Away down the slope , a couple of miles away , [several men]730-several men were advancing , like a row of beaters at a shoot ... [I]0-i dropped out of sight behind the sky - line . That way was shut to [me]0-i , and [I]0-i must try [the bigger hills to the south beyond [the highway]1576-the highway]731-the bigger hills to the south beyond the highway . [The car]514-the car [I]0-i had noticed was getting nearer , but [it]514-the car was still a long way off with some very steep gradients before it . [I]0-i ran hard , crouching low except in [the hollows]734-the hollows , and as [I]0-i ran [I]0-i kept scanning [the brow of [the hill]625-the hill before [me]0-i]735-the brow of the hill before me . Was it imagination , or did [I]0-i see figures - one , two , perhaps more - moving in [a glen beyond [the stream]1666-the stream]737-a glen beyond the stream ? If [you]739-you are hemmed in on all sides in [a patch of land]740-a patch of land there is only one chance of escape . [You]739-you must stay in [the patch]741-the patch , and let [[your]739-you enemies]742-your enemies search [it]741-the patch and not find [you]739-you . That was good sense , but how on earth was [I]0-i to escape notice in that table - cloth of [a place]743-a place ? [I]0-i would have buried [myself]0-i to the neck in mud or lain below water or climbed the tallest tree . But there was not a stick of wood , the bog - holes were little puddles , [the stream]1666-the stream was a slender trickle . There was nothing but short heather , and bare hill bent , and [the white highway]745-the white highway . Then in [a tiny bight of road]746-a tiny bight of road , beside a heap of stones , [I]0-i found [the roadman]747-the roadman . [He]747-the roadman had just arrived , and was wearily flinging down [his]747-the roadman hammer . [He]747-the roadman looked at [me]0-i with a fishy eye and yawned . ' Confoond the day [I]747-the roadman ever left the herdin '[747-the roadman] ! ' [he]747-the roadman said , as if to [the world]309-the world at large . '[747-the roadman] There [I]0-i was [[my]0-i ain maister]748-my ain maister . Now [I]0-i 'm [a slave to [the Goavernment]183-the goavernment]1883-a slave to the goavernment , tethered to the roadside , wi '[747-the roadman] sair een , and a back like a suckle . ' [He]747-the roadman took up the hammer , struck a stone , dropped the implement with an oath , and put both hands to [his]747-the roadman ears . '[747-the roadman] Mercy on [me]0-i ! [My]0-i heid 's burstin ' ! '[747-the roadman] [he]747-the roadman cried . [He]747-the roadman was a wild figure , about [my]0-i own size but much bent , with a week 's beard on [his]747-the roadman chin , and a pair of big horn spectacles . ' [I]747-the roadman canna dae't , '[747-the roadman] [he]747-the roadman cried again . ' [The Surveyor maun]1884-the surveyor maun just report [me]747-the roadman . [I]747-the roadman 'm[747-the roadman] for [my]0-i bed . ' [I]747-the roadman asked [him]747-the roadman what was the trouble , though indeed that was clear enough . '[747-the roadman] The trouble is that [I]0-i 'm [no sober]1885-no sober . Last nicht [my]0-i dochter [Merran]184-merran was waddit , and [they]184-merran danced till fower in the byre . [Me]0-i and [some ither chiels]1886-some ither chiels sat down to the drinkin '[0-i] , and here [I]0-i am . Peety that [I]0-i ever lookit on the wine when it was red ! ' [I]0-i agreed with [him]747-the roadman about bed . '[0-i] It 's easy speakin ' , '[747-the roadman] [he]747-the roadman moaned . [SAVEZ]194-savez ? '[0-i] [I]0-i enjoyed that evening 's ride . Here [we]830-we stopped , and [I]0-i obligingly reversed [the car]514-the car and restored to [Mr Jopley]191-jopley [his]191-jopley belongings . ' A thousand thanks , '[0-i] [I]0-i said . ' There 's more use in [you]191-jopley than [I]0-i thought . Now be off and find [the police]1436-the police . '[0-i] As [I]0-i sat on [the hillside]834-the hillside , watching the tail - light dwindle , [I]0-i reflected on the various kinds of crime [I]0-i had now sampled . Contrary to general belief , [I]0-i was not [a murderer]835-a murderer , but [I]0-i had become [an unholy liar]836-an unholy liar , [a shameless impostor]837-a shameless impostor , and [a highwayman with a marked taste for [expensive motor - cars]839-expensive motor - cars]838-a highwayman with a marked taste for expensive motor - cars . [I]0-i spent the night on a shelf of [the hillside]834-the hillside , in the lee of a boulder where the heather grew long and soft . It was a cold business , for [I]0-i had neither coat nor waistcoat . These were in [[Mr Turnbull]188-mr turnbull 's keeping]841-mr turnbull 's keeping , as was [Scudder]148-scudder 's little book , [my]0-i watch and - worst of all - [my]0-i pipe and tobacco pouch . Only [my]0-i money accompanied [me]0-i in [my]0-i belt , and about half a pound of ginger biscuits in [my]0-i trousers pocket . [I]0-i supped off half those biscuits , and by worming [myself]0-i deep into the heather got some kind of warmth . [My]0-i spirits had risen , and [I]0-i was beginning to enjoy this crazy game of hide - and - seek . So far [I]0-i had been miraculously lucky . [The milkman]474-the milkman , [the literary innkeeper]843-the literary innkeeper , [Sir Harry]177-sir harry , [the roadman]747-the roadman , and [the idiotic Marmie]845-the idiotic marmie , were all pieces of undeserved good fortune . Somehow the first success gave [me]0-i a feeling that [I]0-i was going to pull the thing through . [My]0-i chief trouble was that [I]0-i was desperately hungry . When [a Jew]846-a jew shoots [himself]846-a jew in [the City]240-the city and there is an inquest , the newspapers usually report that [the deceased]405-the deceased was ' well - nourished '[405-the deceased] . [I]0-i remember thinking that [they]849-they would not call [me]0-i well - nourished if [I]0-i broke [my]0-i neck in [a bog - hole]850-a bog - hole . [I]0-i lay and tortured [myself]0-i - for the ginger biscuits merely emphasized the aching void - with the memory of all the good food [I]0-i had thought so little of in [London]1-london . There were [Paddock]851-paddock 's crisp sausages and fragrant shavings of bacon , and shapely poached eggs - how often [I]0-i had turned up [my]0-i nose at them ! There were the cutlets [they]849-they did at [the club]852-the club , and a particular ham that stood on the cold table , for which [my]0-i soul lusted . [My]0-i thoughts hovered over all varieties of mortal edible , and finally settled on a porterhouse steak and a quart of bitter with a welsh rabbit to follow . In longing hopelessly for these dainties [I]0-i fell asleep . [I]0-i woke very cold and stiff about an hour after dawn . It took [me]0-i a little while to remember where [I]0-i was , for [I]0-i had been very weary and had slept heavily . [I]0-i saw first the pale blue sky through a net of heather , then [a big shoulder of hill]853-a big shoulder of hill , and then [my]0-i own boots placed neatly in a blaeberry bush . [I]0-i raised [myself]0-i on [my]0-i arms and looked down into [the valley]624-the valley , and that one look set [me]0-i lacing up [my]0-i boots in mad haste . [Marmie]192-marmie had not been slow in looking for [his]192-marmie revenge . [I]0-i knew very little about [the country]873-the country , and [I]0-i had n't a notion what [I]0-i was going to do .
