There was no carpet on the uneven floor , and nothing to sit down on but a school form . [It]999-it was black as pitch , for the windows were heavily shuttered . [I]0-i made out by groping that the walls were lined with boxes and barrels and sacks of some heavy stuff . [The whole place]1813-the whole place smelt of mould and disuse . [[My]0-i gaolers]1001-my gaolers turned the key in the door , and [I]0-i could hear [them]1001-my gaolers shifting [their]1001-my gaolers feet as [they]1001-my gaolers stood on guard outside . [I]0-i sat down in that chilly darkness in a very miserable frame of mind . [The old boy]1002-the old boy had gone off in [a motor]1003-a motor to collect [the two ruffians who had interviewed [me]0-i yesterday]1004-the two ruffians who had interviewed me yesterday . Now , [they]1004-the two ruffians who had interviewed me yesterday had seen [me]0-i as [the roadman]747-the roadman , and [they]1004-the two ruffians who had interviewed me yesterday would remember [me]0-i , for [I]0-i was in the same rig . What was [a roadman]763-a roadman doing twenty miles from [[his]763-a roadman beat]1007-his beat , pursued by [the police]1436-the police ? A question or two would put [them]1004-the two ruffians who had interviewed me yesterday on the track . Probably [they]1004-the two ruffians who had interviewed me yesterday had seen [Mr Turnbull]188-mr turnbull , probably [Marmie]192-marmie too ; most likely [they]1004-the two ruffians who had interviewed me yesterday could link [me]0-i up with [Sir Harry]177-sir harry , and then the whole thing would be crystal clear . What chance had [I]0-i in [this moorland house]1009-this moorland house with [three desperadoes]1010-three desperadoes and [[their]1010-three desperadoes armed servants]1011-their armed servants ? [I]0-i began to think wistfully of [the police]1436-the police , now plodding over [the hills]1584-the hills after [my]0-i wraith . [They]1436-the police at any rate were [fellow - countrymen]1014-fellow - countrymen and [honest men]1015-honest men , and [their]1436-the police tender mercies would be kinder than [these ghoulish aliens]1016-these ghoulish aliens . But [they]1436-the police would n't have listened to [me]0-i . [That old devil with the eyelids]1017-that old devil with the eyelids had not taken long to get rid of [them]1436-the police . [I]0-i thought [he]1017-that old devil with the eyelids probably had some kind of graft with [the constabulary]1018-the constabulary . Most likely [he]1017-that old devil with the eyelids had letters from [Cabinet Ministers]201-cabinet ministers saying [he]1017-that old devil with the eyelids was to be given every facility for plotting against [Britain]69-britain . That 's the sort of owlish way [we]1019-we run [our]1019-we politics in [the Old Country]241-the old country . [The three]1021-the three would be back for lunch , so [I]0-i had n't more than a couple of hours to wait . [It]1022-it was simply waiting on destruction , for [I]0-i could see no way out of this mess . [I]0-i wished that [I]0-i had [Scudder]148-scudder 's courage , for [I]0-i am free to confess [I]0-i did n't feel any great fortitude . The only thing that kept [me]0-i going was that [I]0-i was pretty furious . It made [me]0-i boil with rage to think of [those three spies]1023-those three spies getting the pull on [me]0-i like this . [I]0-i hoped that at any rate [I]0-i might be able to twist one of [their]1023-those three spies necks before [they]1023-those three spies downed [me]0-i . The more [I]0-i thought of it the angrier [I]0-i grew , and [I]0-i had to get up and move about [the room]1783-the room . [I]0-i tried the shutters , but they were the kind that lock with a key , and [I]0-i could n't move them . From the outside came the faint clucking of hens in the warm sun . Then [I]0-i groped among the sacks and boxes . [I]0-i could n't open the latter , and the sacks seemed to be full of things like dog - biscuits that smelt of cinnamon . But , as [I]0-i circumnavigated [the room]1783-the room , [I]0-i found a handle in the wall which seemed worth investigating . It was the door of a wall cupboard - what [they]1026-they call a ' press '[1026-they] in [Scotland]3-scotland - and it was locked . [I]0-i shook it , and it seemed rather flimsy . For want of something better to do [I]0-i put out [my]0-i strength on that door , getting some purchase on the handle by looping [my]0-i braces round it . Presently the thing gave with a crash which [I]0-i thought would bring in [[my]0-i warders]1027-my warders to inquire . [I]0-i waited for a bit , and then started to explore the cupboard shelves . There was a multitude of queer things there . [I]0-i found an odd vesta or two in [my]0-i trouser pockets and struck a light . It was out in a second , but it showed [me]0-i one thing . There was a little stock of electric torches on one shelf . [I]0-i picked up one , and found it was in working order . With the torch to help [me]0-i [I]0-i investigated further . There were bottles and cases of queer - smelling stuffs , chemicals no doubt for experiments , and there were coils of fine copper wire and yanks and yanks of thin oiled silk . There was a box of detonators , and a lot of cord for fuses . Then away at the back of the shelf [I]0-i found a stout brown cardboard box , and inside it a wooden case . [I]0-i managed to wrench it open , and within lay half a dozen little grey bricks , each a couple of inches square . [I]0-i took up one , and found that it crumbled easily in [my]0-i hand . Then [I]0-i smelt it and put [my]0-i tongue to it . After that [I]0-i sat down to think . [I]0-i had n't been [a mining engineer]418-a mining engineer for nothing , and [I]0-i knew lentonite when [I]0-i saw it . With one of these bricks [I]0-i could blow [the house]1720-the house to smithereens . [I]0-i had used the stuff in [Rhodesia]45-rhodesia and knew [its]1030-its power . But the trouble was that [my]0-i knowledge was n't exact . [I]0-i had forgotten the proper charge and the right way of preparing it , and [I]0-i was n't sure about the timing . [I]0-i had only a vague notion , too , as to [its]1030-its power , for though [I]0-i had used it [I]0-i had not handled it with [my]0-i own fingers . But it was a chance , the only possible chance . It was a mighty risk , but against it was an absolute black certainty . If [I]0-i used it the odds were , as [I]0-i reckoned , about five to one in favour of [my]0-i blowing [myself]0-i into [the tree - tops]1031-the tree - tops ; but if [I]0-i did n't [I]0-i should very likely be occupying a six - foot hole in [the garden]1032-the garden by the evening . That was the way [I]0-i had to look at it . The prospect was pretty dark either way , but anyhow there was a chance , both for [myself]0-i and for [[my]0-i country]1033-my country . The remembrance of [little Scudder]148-scudder decided [me]0-i . It was about the beastliest moment of [my]0-i life , for [I]0-i 'm no good at these cold - blooded resolutions . Still [I]1034-i managed to rake up the pluck to set [my]1034-i teeth and choke back the horrid doubts that flooded in on [me]1034-i . [I]1034-i simply shut off [my]1034-i mind and pretended [I]1034-i was doing an experiment as simple as [Guy Fawkes]202-guy fawkes fireworks . [I]1034-i got a detonator , and fixed it to a couple of feet of fuse . Then [I]1034-i took a quarter of a lentonite brick , and buried it near the door below one of the sacks in a crack of the floor , fixing the detonator in it . For all [I]1034-i knew half those boxes might be dynamite . If the cupboard held such deadly explosives , why not the boxes ? In that case there would be a glorious skyward journey for [me]1034-i and [the German servants]1976-the german servants and about [an acre of surrounding country]1977-an acre of surrounding country . There was also the risk that the detonation might set off the other bricks in the cupboard , for [I]1034-i had forgotten most that [I]1034-i knew about lentonite . But it did n't do to begin thinking about the possibilities . The odds were horrible , but [I]1034-i had to take them . [I]1034-i ensconced [myself]1034-i just below the sill of the window , and lit the fuse . Then [I]1034-i waited for a moment or two . There was dead silence - only a shuffle of heavy boots in [the passage]1978-the passage , and the peaceful cluck of hens from the warm out - of - doors . [I]1034-i commended [my]1034-i soul to [[my]1034-i Maker]1979-my maker , and wondered where [I]1034-i would be in five seconds ... A great wave of heat seemed to surge upwards from the floor , and hang for a blistering instant in the air . Then the wall opposite [me]1034-i flashed into a golden yellow and dissolved with a rending thunder that hammered [my]1034-i brain into a pulp . Something dropped on [me]1034-i , catching the point of [my]1034-i left shoulder . And then [I]1034-i think [I]1034-i became unconscious . [My]1034-i stupor can scarcely have lasted beyond a few seconds . [I]1034-i felt [myself]1034-i being choked by thick yellow fumes , and struggled out of the debris to [my]1034-i feet . Somewhere behind [me]1034-i [I]1034-i felt fresh air . The jambs of the window had fallen , and through the ragged rent the smoke was pouring out to the summer noon . [I]1034-i stepped over the broken lintel , and found [myself]1034-i standing in [a yard]1980-a yard in a dense and acrid fog . [I]1034-i felt very sick and ill , but [I]1034-i could move [my]1034-i limbs , and [I]1034-i staggered blindly forward away from [the house]1720-the house . [A small mill - lade]1982-a small mill - lade ran in a wooden aqueduct at the other side of [the yard]1983-the yard , and into this [I]1034-i fell . The cool water revived [me]1034-i , and [I]1034-i had just enough wits left to think of escape . [I]1034-i squirmed up the lade among the slippery green slime till [I]1034-i reached the mill - wheel . Then [I]1034-i wriggled through the axle hole into [the old mill]1984-the old mill and tumbled on to a bed of chaff . A nail caught the seat of [my]1034-i trousers , and [I]1034-i left a wisp of heather - mixture behind [me]1034-i . [The mill]1985-the mill had been long out of use . The ladders were rotten with age , and in [the loft]488-the loft the rats had gnawed great holes in the floor . Nausea shook [me]1034-i , and a wheel in [my]1034-i head kept turning , while [my]1034-i left shoulder and arm seemed to be stricken with the palsy . [I]1034-i looked out of the window and saw a fog still hanging over [the house]1720-the house and smoke escaping from an upper window . [Please God]147-god [I]1034-i had set [the place]380-the place on fire , for [I]1034-i could hear confused cries coming from the other side . But [I]1034-i had no time to linger , since [this mill]1989-this mill was obviously a bad hiding - place . Anyone looking for [me]1034-i would naturally follow the lade , and [I]1034-i made certain the search would begin as soon as [they]1990-they found that [my]1034-i body was not in [the storeroom]1975-the storeroom . From another window [I]1034-i saw that on the far side of [the mill]1985-the mill stood [an old stone dovecot]1993-an old stone dovecot . If [I]1034-i could get there without leaving [tracks]1994-tracks [I]1034-i might find a hiding - place , for [I]1034-i argued that [[my]1034-i enemies]1704-my enemies , if [they]1704-my enemies thought [I]1034-i could move , would conclude [I]1034-i had made for [open country]1996-open country , and would go seeking [me]1034-i on [the moor]1611-the moor . [I]1034-i crawled down the broken ladder , scattering chaff behind [me]1034-i to cover [my]1034-i footsteps . [I]1034-i did the same on the mill floor , and on the threshold where the door hung on broken hinges . Peeping out , [I]1034-i saw that between [me]1034-i and [the dovecot]1998-the dovecot was a piece of bare cobbled ground , where no footmarks would show . Also it was mercifully hid by [the mill buildings]1999-the mill buildings from any view from [the house]1720-the house . [I]1034-i slipped across [the space]2001-the space , got to the back of [the dovecot]1998-the dovecot and prospected a way of ascent . That was one of the hardest jobs [I]1034-i ever took on . [My]1034-i shoulder and arm ached like hell , and [I]1034-i was so sick and giddy that [I]1034-i was always on the verge of falling . But [I]1034-i managed it somehow . By the use of out - jutting stones and gaps in the masonry and a tough ivy root [I]1034-i got to the top in the end . There was a little parapet behind which [I]1034-i found [space to lie down]2003-space to lie down . Then [I]1034-i proceeded to go off into an old - fashioned swoon . [I]1034-i woke with a burning head and the sun glaring in [my]1034-i face . For a long time [I]1034-i lay motionless , for those horrible fumes seemed to have loosened [my]1034-i joints and dulled [my]1034-i brain . Sounds came to [me]1034-i from [the house]1720-the house - [men]422-men speaking throatily and the throbbing of [a stationary car]2006-a stationary car . There was a little gap in the parapet to which [I]1034-i wriggled , and from which [I]1034-i had some sort of prospect of [the yard]1983-the yard . [I]1034-i saw [figures]2008-figures come out - [a servant]2009-a servant with [his]2009-a servant head bound up , and then [a younger man in knickerbockers]2010-a younger man in knickerbockers . [They]2008-figures were looking for something , and moved towards [the mill]1985-the mill . Then one of [them]2008-figures caught sight of the wisp of cloth on the nail , and cried out to the other . [They]2008-figures both went back to [the house]1720-the house , and brought [two more]2013-two more to look at [it]1985-the mill . [I]1034-i saw [the rotund figure of [[my]1034-i late captor]2015-my late captor]2014-the rotund figure of my late captor , and [I]1034-i thought [I]1034-i made out [the man with the lisp]2016-the man with the lisp . [I]1034-i noticed that [all]2017-all had pistols . For half an hour [they]2008-figures ransacked [the mill]1985-the mill . [I]1034-i could hear [them]2008-figures kicking over the barrels and pulling up the rotten planking . Then [they]2008-figures came outside , and stood just below [the dovecot]1998-the dovecot arguing fiercely . [The servant with the bandage]2020-the servant with the bandage was being soundly rated . [I]1034-i heard [them]2008-figures fiddling with the door of [the dovecote]2021-the dovecote and for one horrid moment [I]1034-i fancied [they]2008-figures were coming up . Then [they]2008-figures thought better of it , and went back to [the house]1720-the house . All that long blistering afternoon [I]1034-i lay baking on [the rooftop]2023-the rooftop . [Thirst]203-thirst was [my]1034-i chief torment . [My]1034-i tongue was like a stick , and to make it worse [I]1034-i could hear the cool drip of water from the mill - lade . [I]1034-i watched the course of [the little stream]2024-the little stream as it came in from [the moor]1611-the moor , and [my]1034-i fancy followed it to [the top of [the glen]1712-the glen]2026-the top of the glen , where it must issue from [an icy fountain fringed with cool ferns and mosses]2028-an icy fountain fringed with cool ferns and mosses . [I]1034-i would have given a thousand pounds to plunge [my]1034-i face into that . [I]1034-i had a fine prospect of the whole ring of moorland . [I]1034-i saw [the car]514-the car speed away with [two occupants]2030-two occupants , and [a man on a hill pony riding east]2031-a man on a hill pony riding east . [I]1034-i judged [they]2030-two occupants were looking for [me]1034-i , and [I]1034-i wished [them]2030-two occupants joy of [their]2030-two occupants quest . But [I]1034-i saw something else more interesting . [The house]1720-the house stood almost on the summit of [a swell of moorland which crowned [a sort of plateau]2034-a sort of plateau]2033-a swell of moorland which crowned a sort of plateau , and there was [no higher point nearer than [the big hills six miles off]2036-the big hills six miles off]2035-no higher point nearer than the big hills six miles off . [The actual summit]2037-the actual summit , as [I]1034-i have mentioned , was a biggish clump of trees - firs mostly , with a few ashes and beeches . On [the dovecot]1998-the dovecot [I]1034-i was almost on a level with the tree - tops , and could see what lay beyond . The wood was not solid , but only a ring , and inside was an oval of green turf , for [all the world]2039-all the world like [a big cricket - field]2040-a big cricket - field . [I]1034-i did n't take long to guess what it was . It was [an aerodrome]2041-an aerodrome , and [a secret one]2042-a secret one . [The place]380-the place had been most cunningly chosen . For suppose [anyone]242-anyone were watching [an aeroplane]706-an aeroplane descending here , [he]242-anyone would think it had gone over [the hill beyond the trees]2046-the hill beyond the trees . As [the place]380-the place was on the top of a rise in the midst of [a big amphitheatre]2048-a big amphitheatre , [any observer from any direction]2049-any observer from any direction would conclude [it]706-an aeroplane had passed out of view behind [the hill]625-the hill . Only [a man very close at hand]2051-a man very close at hand would realize that [the aeroplane]622-the aeroplane had not gone over but had descended in the midst of [the wood]2053-the wood . [An observer with a telescope on one of [the higher hills]2055-the higher hills]2054-an observer with a telescope on one of the higher hills might have discovered the truth , but only [herds]2056-herds went there , and herds do not carry spy - glasses . When [I]1034-i looked from [the dovecot]1998-the dovecot [I]1034-i could see far away a blue line which [I]1034-i knew was [the sea]2058-the sea , and [I]1034-i grew furious to think that [[our]2059-our enemies]2060-our enemies had this secret conning - tower to rake [[our]2059-our waterways]2061-our waterways . Then [I]1034-i reflected that if [that aeroplane]1698-that aeroplane came back the chances were ten to one that [I]1034-i would be discovered . So through the afternoon [I]1034-i lay and prayed for the coming of darkness , and glad [I]1034-i was when the sun went down over [the big western hills]2063-the big western hills and the twilight haze crept over [the moor]1611-the moor . [The aeroplane]622-the aeroplane was late . The gloaming was far advanced when [I]1034-i heard the beat of wings and saw [it]622-the aeroplane volplaning downward to [its]622-the aeroplane home in [the wood]2053-the wood . Lights twinkled for a bit and there was much coming and going from [the house]1720-the house . Then the dark fell , and silence . Thank God it was a black night . The moon was well on its last quarter and would not rise till late . [My]1034-i thirst was too great to allow [me]1034-i to tarry , so about nine o'clock , so far as [I]1034-i could judge , [I]1034-i started to descend . It was n't easy , and half - way down [I]1034-i heard the back door of [the house]1720-the house open , and saw the gleam of a lantern against the mill wall . For some agonizing minutes [I]1034-i hung by the ivy and prayed that whoever it was would not come round by the dovecot . Then the light disappeared , and [I]1034-i dropped as softly as [I]1034-i could on to the hard soil of [the yard]1983-the yard . [I]1034-i crawled on [my]1034-i belly in the lee of [a stone dyke]2070-a stone dyke till [I]1034-i reached the fringe of trees which surrounded [the house]1720-the house . If [I]1034-i had known how to do it [I]1034-i would have tried to put [that aeroplane]1698-that aeroplane out of action , but [I]1034-i realized that any attempt would probably be futile . [I]1034-i was pretty certain that there would be some kind of defence round [the house]1720-the house , so [I]1034-i went through the wood on hands and knees , feeling carefully every inch before [me]1034-i . It was as well , for presently [I]1034-i came on a wire about two feet from the ground . If [I]1034-i had tripped over that , it would doubtless have rung some bell in [the house]1720-the house and [I]1034-i would have been captured . A hundred yards farther on [I]1034-i found another wire cunningly placed on the edge of [a small stream]2075-a small stream . Beyond that lay [the moor]1611-the moor , and in five minutes [I]1034-i was deep in bracken and heather . Soon [I]1034-i was round the shoulder of the rise , in [the little glen from which [the mill - lade flowed]2078-the mill - lade flowed]2077-the little glen from which the mill - lade flowed . Ten minutes later [my]1034-i face was in the spring , and [I]1034-i was soaking down pints of the blessed water . But [I]1034-i did not stop till [I]1034-i had put half a dozen miles between [me]1034-i and [that accursed dwelling]2079-that accursed dwelling . [I]1034-i sat down on [a hill - top]2080-a hill - top and took stock of [my]1034-i position . [I]1034-i was n't feeling very happy , for [my]1034-i natural thankfulness at [my]1034-i escape was clouded by [my]1034-i severe bodily discomfort . Those lentonite fumes had fairly poisoned [me]1034-i , and the baking hours on [the dovecot]1998-the dovecot had n't helped matters . [I]1034-i had a crushing headache , and felt as sick as a cat . Also [my]1034-i shoulder was in a bad way . At first [I]1034-i thought it was only a bruise , but it seemed to be swelling , and [I]1034-i had no use of [my]1034-i left arm . [My]1034-i plan was to seek [[Mr Turnbull]188-mr turnbull 's cottage]2082-mr turnbull 's cottage , recover [my]1034-i garments , and especially [Scudder]148-scudder 's note - book , and then make for the main line and get back to [the south]683-the south . It seemed to [me]1034-i that the sooner [I]1034-i got in touch with [the Foreign Office man]2084-the foreign office man , [Sir Walter Bullivant]182-sir walter , the better . [I]1034-i did n't see how [I]1034-i could get more proof than [I]1034-i had got already . [He]2084-the foreign office man must just take or leave [my]1034-i story , and anyway , with [him]2084-the foreign office man [I]1034-i would be in better hands than [those devilish Germans]2085-those devilish germans . [I]1034-i had begun to feel quite kindly towards [the British police]471-the british police . It was a wonderful starry night , and [I]1034-i had not much difficulty about [the road]1715-the road . [Sir Harry]177-sir harry 's map had given [me]1034-i the lie of [the land]585-the land , and all [I]1034-i had to do was to steer a point or two west of [south - west]2089-south - west to come to [the stream where [I]1034-i had met [the roadman]747-the roadman]2090-the stream where i had met the roadman . In all these travels [I]1034-i never knew the names of [the places]2092-the places , but [I]1034-i believe [this stream]2093-this stream was no less than [the upper waters of [the river Tweed]87-the river tweed]2094-the upper waters of the river tweed . [I]1034-i calculated [I]1034-i must be about eighteen miles distant , and that meant [I]1034-i could not get [there]246-there before morning . So [I]1034-i must lie up a day somewhere , for [I]1034-i was too outrageous a figure to be seen in the sunlight . [I]1034-i had neither coat , waistcoat , collar , nor hat , [my]1034-i trousers were badly torn , and [my]1034-i face and hands were black with the explosion . [I]1034-i daresay [I]1034-i had other beauties , for [my]1034-i eyes felt as if they were furiously bloodshot . Altogether [I]1034-i was no spectacle for [God - fearing citizens]2096-god - fearing citizens to see on [a highroad]2097-a highroad . Very soon after daybreak [I]1034-i made an attempt to clean [myself]1034-i in [a hill burn]2098-a hill burn , and then approached [[a herd]2099-a herd 's cottage]2100-a herd 's cottage , for [I]1034-i was feeling the need of food . [The herd]2101-the herd was away from [home]245-home , and [[his]2101-the herd wife]2103-his wife was alone , with [no neighbour]2104-no neighbour for five miles . [She]2103-his wife was [a decent old body]2105-a decent old body , and [a plucky one]2106-a plucky one , for though [she]2103-his wife got a fright when [she]2103-his wife saw [me]1034-i , [she]2103-his wife had an axe handy , and would have used it on [any evil - doer]2107-any evil - doer . [I]1034-i told [her]2103-his wife that [I]1034-i had had a fall - [I]1034-i did n't say how - and [she]2103-his wife saw by [my]1034-i looks that [I]1034-i was pretty sick . Like [a true Samaritan]2108-a true samaritan [she]2103-his wife asked no questions , but gave [me]1034-i a bowl of milk with a dash of whisky in it , and let [me]1034-i sit for a little by [her]2103-his wife kitchen fire . [She]2103-his wife would have bathed [my]1034-i shoulder , but it ached so badly that [I]1034-i would not let [her]2103-his wife touch it . [I]1034-i do n't know what [she]2103-his wife took [me]1034-i for - [a repentant burglar]2109-a repentant burglar , perhaps ; for when [I]1034-i wanted to pay [her]2103-his wife for the milk and tendered a sovereign which was the smallest coin [I]1034-i had , [she]2103-his wife shook [her]2103-his wife head and said something about '[1034-i] giving it to [them]1034-i that had a right to it ' . At this [I]344-man protested so strongly that [I]344-man think [she]2103-his wife believed [me]344-man honest , for [she]2103-his wife took the money and gave [me]344-man a warm new plaid for it , and an old hat of [[her]2103-his wife man]1583-her man 's . [She]2103-his wife showed [me]344-man how to wrap the plaid around [my]344-man shoulders , and when [I]344-man left [that cottage]2111-that cottage [I]344-man was the living image of [the kind of Scotsman [you]2113-you see in the illustrations to [Burns]204-burns 's poems]2112-the kind of scotsman you see in the illustrations to burns 's poems . But at any rate [I]344-man was more or less clad . It was as well , for the weather changed before midday to a thick drizzle of rain . [I]344-man found shelter below an overhanging rock in the crook of a burn , where [a drift of dead brackens]2114-a drift of dead brackens made a tolerable bed . [There]246-there [I]344-man managed to sleep till nightfall , waking very cramped and wretched , with [my]344-man shoulder gnawing like a toothache . [I]344-man ate the oatcake and cheese [the old wife]2116-the old wife had given [me]344-man and set out again just before the darkening . [I]344-man pass over the miseries of that night among [the wet hills]2117-the wet hills . There were no stars to steer by , and [I]344-man had to do the best [I]344-man could from [my]344-man memory of the map . Twice [I]344-man lost [my]344-man way , and [I]344-man had some nasty falls into [peat - bogs]2118-peat - bogs . [I]344-man had only about ten miles to go as the crow flies , but [my]344-man mistakes made it nearer twenty . The last bit was completed with set teeth and a very light and dizzy head . But [I]344-man managed it , and in the early dawn [I]344-man was knocking at [Mr Turnbull]188-mr turnbull 's door . The mist lay close and thick , and from [the cottage]2119-the cottage [I]344-man could not see [the highroad]723-the highroad . [Mr Turnbull]188-mr turnbull [himself]188-mr turnbull opened to [me]344-man - sober and something more than sober . [He]188-mr turnbull was primly dressed in an ancient but well - tended suit of black ; [he]188-mr turnbull had been shaved not later than the night before ; [he]188-mr turnbull wore a linen collar ; and in [his]188-mr turnbull left hand [he]188-mr turnbull carried a pocket Bible . At first [he]188-mr turnbull did not recognize [me]344-man . '[344-man] Whae are [ye]1035-ye that comes stravaigin ' here on the Sabbath mornin '[344-man] ? ' [he]188-mr turnbull asked . [I]344-man had lost all count of the days . So the Sabbath was the reason for this strange decorum . [My]344-man head was swimming so wildly that [I]344-man could not frame a coherent answer . But [he]188-mr turnbull recognized [me]344-man , and [he]188-mr turnbull saw that [I]344-man was ill . '[344-man] Hae [ye]1035-ye got [my]0-i specs ? ' [he]188-mr turnbull asked . '[1035-ye] Come in - bye . Losh , [man]344-man , [ye're]1035-ye terrible dune [i]0-i ' the legs . Haud up till [I]0-i get [ye]1035-ye to a chair . '[0-i] [I]0-i perceived [I]0-i was in for a bout of malaria . [I]0-i had a good deal of fever in [my]0-i bones , and the wet night had brought it out , while [my]0-i shoulder and the effects of the fumes combined to make [me]0-i feel pretty bad . Before [I]0-i knew , [Mr Turnbull]188-mr turnbull was helping [me]0-i off with [my]0-i clothes , and putting [me]0-i to bed in one of the two cupboards that lined the kitchen walls . [He]188-mr turnbull was [a true friend in need]1037-a true friend in need , [that old roadman]1038-that old roadman . [[His]188-mr turnbull wife]2103-his wife was dead years ago , and since [[his]188-mr turnbull daughter]1040-his daughter 's marriage [he]188-mr turnbull lived alone . For the better part of ten days [he]188-mr turnbull did all the rough nursing [I]0-i needed . [I]0-i simply wanted to be left in peace while the fever took its course , and when [my]0-i skin was cool again [I]0-i found that the bout had more or less cured [my]0-i shoulder . But it was a baddish go , and though [I]0-i was out of bed in five days , it took [me]0-i some time to get [my]0-i legs again . [He]188-mr turnbull went out each morning , leaving [me]0-i milk for the day , and locking the door behind [him]188-mr turnbull ; and came in in the evening to sit silent in the chimney corner . [Not a soul]1041-not a soul came near [the place]380-the place . When [I]0-i was getting better , [he]188-mr turnbull never bothered [me]0-i with a question . [My]181-annie laurie plaid and [my]181-annie laurie old hat , as [I]181-annie laurie have said , gave [me]181-annie laurie a fine theatrical Scots look . But driving cattle is a mortally slow job , and [we]1050-we took the better part of the day to cover a dozen miles . If [I]181-annie laurie had not had such an anxious heart [I]181-annie laurie would have enjoyed that time . It was shining blue weather , with a constantly changing prospect of [brown hills]2128-brown hills and [far green meadows]2129-far green meadows , and a continual sound of larks and curlews and falling streams . [I]181-annie laurie all but slept too long , and had to run to [the station]1610-the station and catch [the train]1516-the train with two minutes to spare . [I]0-i heard a whistle being blown , and the rush of [men]422-men behind [me]0-i . [I]0-i have a very fair turn of speed , and that night [I]0-i had wings . [I]0-i was staking all on getting to [Queen Anne 's Gate]106-queen anne 's gate . When [I]0-i entered [that quiet thoroughfare]2244-that quiet thoroughfare [it]2244-that quiet thoroughfare seemed deserted . [I]0-i slackened speed some yards off and walked briskly up to the door . [I]222-germans sat at the desk and [the others]293-the others stood round , for somehow or other [I]222-germans had got charge of this expedition . It was no good . There were hundreds of entries , and so far as [I]222-germans could see 10.17 might cover fifty places . [We]2327-we had to find some way of narrowing the possibilities . [I]222-germans took [my]222-germans head in [my]222-germans hands and thought . There must be some way of reading this riddle . What did [Scudder]148-scudder mean by steps ? [I]222-germans thought of dock steps , but if [he]148-scudder had meant that [I]222-germans did n't think [he]148-scudder would have mentioned the number . Then [I]222-germans had a sudden thought , and hunted up [all the steamer sailings]2339-all the steamer sailings . There was [no boat which left for]2340-no boat which left for [the Continent]2341-the continent at 10.17 p.m. Why was high tide so important ? If [it]2342-it was [a harbour]2343-a harbour [it]2342-it must be [some little place where the tide mattered]2344-some little place where the tide mattered , or else it was [a heavy - draught boat]2345-a heavy - draught boat . But there was [no regular steamer sailing]2346-no regular steamer sailing at that hour , and somehow [I]222-germans did n't think [they]2347-they would travel by a big boat from [a regular harbour]2348-a regular harbour . So it must be [some little harbour where the tide was important , or perhaps no harbour at all]2349-some little harbour where the tide was important , or perhaps no harbour at all . But if it was [a little port]2350-a little port [I]222-germans could n't see what the steps signified . There were no sets of staircases on [any harbour that [I]222-germans had ever seen]2351-any harbour that i had ever seen . It must be some place which a particular staircase identified , and where the tide was full at 10.17 . On the whole it seemed to [me]222-germans that [the place]380-the place must be [a bit of open coast]2353-a bit of open coast . But the staircases kept puzzling [me]222-germans . Then [I]222-germans went back to wider considerations . Whereabouts would [a man]269-a man be likely to leave for [Germany]22-germany , [a man in a hurry , who wanted a speedy and a secret passage]2355-a man in a hurry , who wanted a speedy and a secret passage ? Not from [any of [the big harbours]2357-the big harbours]2356-any of the big harbours . And not from [the Channel]113-the channel or [the West Coast]114-the west coast or [Scotland]3-scotland , for , remember , [he]269-a man was starting from [London]1-london . [I]222-germans measured the distance on the map , and tried to put [myself]222-germans in [the enemy]455-the enemy 's shoes . [I]222-germans should try for [Ostend]115-ostend or [Antwerp]116-antwerp or [Rotterdam]117-rotterdam , and [I]222-germans should sail from [somewhere on [the East Coast]118-the east coast between [Cromer]119-cromer and [Dover]103-dover]2359-somewhere on the east coast between cromer and dover . All this was very loose guessing , and [I]222-germans do n't pretend it was ingenious or scientific . [I]222-germans was n't any kind of [Sherlock Holmes]223-sherlock holmes . But [I]222-germans have always fancied [I]222-germans had a kind of instinct about questions like this . [I]222-germans do n't know if [I]222-germans can explain [myself]222-germans , but [I]222-germans used to use [my]222-germans brains as far as [they]2360-they went , and after [they]2360-they came to a blank wall [I]222-germans guessed , and [I]222-germans usually found [my]222-germans guesses pretty right . So [I]222-germans set out all [my]222-germans conclusions on a bit of Admiralty paper . [They]2360-they ran like this : FAIRLY CERTAIN ( 1 ) Place where there are [several sets of stairs]2361-several sets of stairs ; one that matters distinguished by having thirty - nine steps . ( 2 ) Full tide at 10.17 p.m. Leaving [shore]971-shore only possible at full tide . ( 3 ) Steps not dock steps , and so place probably not [harbour]2363-harbour . ( 4 ) [No regular night steamer]2364-no regular night steamer at 10.17 . [Means of transport]2365-means of transport must be [tramp ( unlikely ) , yacht]2366-tramp ( unlikely ) , yacht , or [fishing - boat]2367-fishing - boat . There [my]222-germans reasoning stopped . [I]222-germans made another list , which [I]222-germans headed '[222-germans] Guessed ' , but [I]222-germans was just as sure of the one as the other . ( 3 ) [Place somewhere on [East Coast]118-the east coast between [Cromer]119-cromer and [Dover]103-dover]2371-place somewhere on east coast between cromer and dover . And yet there were [three of [them]2400-these three hearty fellows]2402-three of them ; and one was old , and one was plump , and one was lean and dark ; and [[their]2400-these three hearty fellows house]2403-their house chimed in with [Scudder]148-scudder 's notes ; and half a mile off was lying [a steam yacht]2404-a steam yacht with at least [one German officer]2405-one german officer . [I]0-i thought of [Karolides]141-karolides lying dead and all [Europe]11-europe trembling on the edge of earthquake , and [the men [I]0-i had left behind [me]0-i in [London]1-london who were waiting anxiously for the events of the next hours]2406-the men i had left behind me in london who were waiting anxiously for the events of the next hours . There was no doubt that hell was afoot somewhere . [The Black Stone]154-the black stone had won , and if it survived this June night would bank its winnings . There seemed only one thing to do - go forward as if [I]0-i had no doubts , and if [I]0-i was going to make a fool of [myself]0-i to do it handsomely . Never in [my]0-i life have [I]0-i faced a job with greater disinclination . [I]1397-i wondered if [he]1377-the plump man was [the fellow who had first tracked [Scudder]146-scudder]2548-the fellow who had first tracked scudder , and left [his]1377-the plump man card on [him]1377-the plump man . But [the old man]1357-the old man was the pick of [the lot]2550-the lot . [He]1377-the plump man was sheer brain , icy , cool , calculating , as ruthless as a steam hammer . Now that [my]1397-i eyes were opened [I]1397-i wondered where [I]1397-i had seen the benevolence . [His]1357-the old man jaw was like chilled steel , and [his]1357-the old man eyes had the inhuman luminosity of a bird 's . [I]1397-i went on playing , and every second a greater hate welled up in [my]1397-i heart . It almost choked [me]1397-i , and [I]1397-i could n't answer when [[my]1397-i partner]2536-my partner spoke . Only a little longer could [I]1397-i endure [their]2536-my partner company . '[1397-i] Whew ! [Bob]228-bob ! Look at the time , ' said [the old man]1357-the old man . '[228-bob] [You]228-bob 'd better think about catching [your]228-bob train . [Bob]228-bob 's got to go to [town]1120-town tonight , ' [he]1357-the old man added , turning to [me]228-bob . The voice rang now as false as hell . [I]228-bob looked at the clock , and it was nearly half - past ten . '[228-bob] [I]0-i am afraid [he]228-bob must put off [his]228-bob journey , ' [I]228-bob said . [You]228-bob can have [my]0-i address , and [I]0-i 'll give any security [you]228-bob like . ' '[0-i] No , ' [I]228-bob said , '[228-bob] [you]228-bob must stay . ' At that [I]0-i think [they]2554-they must have realized that the game was desperate . [Their]2554-they only chance had been to convince [me]0-i that [I]0-i was playing [the fool]480-the fool , and that had failed . But [the old man]1357-the old man spoke again . '[0-i] [I]0-i 'll go bail for [[my]0-i nephew]1408-my nephew . That ought to content [you]228-bob , [Mr Hannay]140-mr hannay . ' Was it fancy , or did [I]236-schnell detect some halt in the smoothness of that voice ? There must have been , for as [I]236-schnell glanced at [him]1357-the old man , [his]1357-the old man eyelids fell in that hawk - like hood which fear had stamped on [my]236-schnell memory . [I]236-schnell blew [my]236-schnell whistle . In an instant the lights were out . A pair of strong arms gripped [me]236-schnell round the waist , covering the pockets in which [a man]269-a man might be expected to carry a pistol . '[236-schnell] [Schnell]236-schnell , [Franz]237-franz , ' cried a voice , '[236-schnell] [Das Boot]238-das boot , [das Boot]1409-das boot ! ' As it spoke [I]1409-das boot saw [two of [[my]1409-das boot fellows]2559-my fellows emerge on [the moonlit lawn]2560-the moonlit lawn]2558-two of my fellows emerge on the moonlit lawn . [The young dark man]2561-the young dark man leapt for the window , was through it , and over the low fence before a hand could touch [him]1357-the old man . [I]1409-das boot grappled [the old chap]2562-the old chap , and [the room]1783-the room seemed to fill with figures . [I]1409-das boot saw [the plump one collared]2564-the plump one collared , but [my]1409-das boot eyes were all for the out - of - doors , where [Franz]237-franz sped on over [the road]1715-the road towards [the railed entrance to [the beach stairs]2567-the beach stairs]2566-the railed entrance to the beach stairs . [One man]1931-one man followed [him]2561-the young dark man , but [he]1931-one man had no chance . The gate of [the stairs]2569-the stairs locked behind [the fugitive]2412-the fugitive , and [I]1409-das boot stood staring , with [my]1409-das boot hands on [the old boy]1002-the old boy 's throat , for such a time as [a man]269-a man might take to descend those steps to [the sea]2058-the sea . Suddenly [[my]1409-das boot prisoner]2574-my prisoner broke from [me]1409-das boot and flung [himself]2574-my prisoner on the wall . There was a click as if a lever had been pulled . Then came a low rumbling far , far below the ground , and through the window [I]1409-das boot saw a cloud of chalky dust pouring out of the shaft of [the stairway]2575-the stairway . [Someone]452-someone switched on the light . [The old man]1357-the old man was looking at [me]1409-das boot with blazing eyes . '[1409-das boot] [He]1410-he is safe , ' [he]1357-the old man cried . '[1411-you] [You]1411-you can not follow in time ... [He]1410-he is gone ... [He]1410-he has triumphed ... [Der Schwarze Stein]239-der schwarze stein ist in [der Siegeskrone]138-der siegeskrone . ' There was more in those eyes than any common triumph . [They]2578-they had been hooded like a bird of prey , and now they flamed with a hawk 's pride . A white fanatic heat burned in [them]2578-they , and [I]239-der schwarze stein realized for the first time the terrible thing [I]239-der schwarze stein had been up against . [This man]1858-this man was more than [a spy]2580-a spy ; in [his]1858-this man foul way [he]1858-this man had been [a patriot]2581-a patriot . '[239-der schwarze stein] [I]0-i hope [Franz]237-franz will bear [his]1410-he triumph well . ' Three weeks later , as all [the world]309-the world knows , [we]1413-our went to war .
